1.title: Simple Present
1.content:
The Simple Present is used to describe habits, general truths, repeated actions, or unchanging situations, emotions, and wishes. It describes facts and scheduled events.

Structure (Affirmative):

Subject + Base Verb (+s/es)

Structure (Negative):

Subject + do/does not + Base Verb

Structure (Question):

Do/Does + Subject + Base Verb?

Examples:

  • This function returns an array of objects.
  • We have a daily stand-up meeting at 9 AM.
  • The new module doesn't handle that specific case.
  • Does the script run automatically?
  • APIs provide a way for systems to communicate.
  • The build process takes about five minutes.

2.title: Subject Questions (Unknown Subject)
2.content:
The master logic for forming a subject question starts with the base: Do I know the SUBJECT (the doer of the action)?

If the answer is NO (because the question word Who, What, or Which IS the subject you are looking for), the structure DOES NOT require INVERSION. The question maintains the exact word order of an affirmative statement.

Master Structure:

Who/What/Which (Subject) + Verb Block + (Object)?

1. Simple Present & Past (No Do / Does / Did)

In simple tenses, we do not use auxiliaries. The verb is conjugated directly according to the tense.

  • Who lives here?
  • Who called you?
  • What happened?
  • Who needs help?
  • Which script failed?
  • What went wrong?

2. Continuous Tenses (Auxiliary without Inversion)

The auxiliary appears but follows the subject in normal statement order.

  • Who is winning?
  • What is burning?
  • Who is calling you?
  • What was making that noise?

3. Perfect Tenses (Auxiliary without Inversion)

The auxiliary (has/have/had) stays in its original position after the subject.

  • What has changed?
  • Who has finished?
  • Which team has won?
  • What had happened before the crash?

4. With Modal Verbs (Modal without Inversion)

The modal (can, will, should, etc.) directly follows the subject.

  • Who can help us?
  • What will happen tomorrow?
  • Who should lead the project?
  • Which version could work?

3.title: Standard Questions (Known Subject)
3.content:
The master logic for forming a real question in English starts with one question: Do I know the SUBJECT (the doer of the action)?

If the answer is YES, the structure requires INVERSION. This means the 'verb' (To Be, Auxiliary, or Modal) must jump in front of the subject.

Master Structure:

(Wh- word) + Verb/Aux + Subject + (extra)...?

1. With "To Be" (Direct Inversion)

No extra auxiliaries needed; simply swap the order of the subject and the verb.

  • Are you right?
  • Is the server down?
  • Where was she?
  • Why are components lagging?

2. Simple Present & Past (Do / Does / Did)

The key rule is that we must use an auxiliary verb (do, does, did) in simple tenses because the main verb cannot jump alone. The main verb always returns to its Base Form.

  • What did you say?
  • Where does he work?
  • Why did the deployment fail?
  • Which button did you click?
  • How do these values get updated?
  • Does this ticket have criteria?

3. With Modal Verbs

The modal is placed directly before the subject.

  • What should I do?
  • Who can we ask?
  • Will the nickname stick to him?
  • How could they fix it?
  • Will the offer appeal to me?
  • Where would you go?

4. Perfect Tenses (Have / Has / Had)

The first auxiliary jumps before the subject.

  • Who have you met?
  • What has changed?
  • Had they finished the task?
  • What have we done?

5. Who and What as OBJECTS

When asking about the receiver of the action.

  • Who did you call?
  • What do you want?
  • Who does she love?
  • Who does this belong to?

4.title: Negative Questions
4.content:
Negative Questions start with a negative auxiliary verb (e.g., Don't, Isn't, Shouldn't). They are very common in conversation and are typically used in two main ways:

  1. To confirm something you believe is true: You expect the listener to agree with you.
  2. To express surprise, concern, or persuasion: You are highlighting something unexpected or trying to convince someone.

Structure:

Negative Auxiliary + Subject + Main Verb?

Common Examples:

  • (Confirmation) Don't you think this is too complex?
  • (Confirmation) Didn't we fix this issue already?
  • (Surprise) Isn't that the file you were looking for?
  • (Confirmation) Aren't those the requirements we agreed on?
  • (Past Expectation) Shouldn't we have tested this edge case?
  • (Surprise) Hasn't he finished his part yet?
  • (Surprise) Haven't you seen the new mockups?
  • (Concern) Won't this change affect the production server?
  • (Persuasion) Can't you just revert the last commit?
  • (Confirmation) Couldn't you find the file in the shared drive?
  • (Suggestion) Wouldn't it be better to wait until Monday?
  • (Expectation) Weren't you supposed to be in that meeting?

5.title: Present Perfect
5.content:
The Present Perfect connects the past with the present. It is used for actions that happened at an unspecified time in the past, or actions that started in the past and continue to the present. The focus is on the result.

Structure:

Subject + have/has + Past Participle

Examples:

  • I have finished the report. (Result: It is ready now)
  • She has worked at Google for ten years. (She still works there)
  • We have seen that error before. (Experience)
  • He hasn't completed the task yet.
  • Have you updated the database?
  • They have just launched the new feature.
  • The server has crashed three times today.
  • I have never used that library.
  • She has lost her access keys.
  • Has the client approved the design?

6.title: Present Perfect Continuous
6.content:
Used for actions that started in the past and are still in progress or have recently stopped. It emphasizes the duration or the continuous nature of the activity.

Structure:

Subject + have/has been + Verb-ing

Examples:

  • I have been coding for five hours straight.
  • She has been trying to fix this bug all morning.
  • We have been waiting for the API response since 9 AM.
  • They have been discussing the requirements for days.
  • It has been raining heavily all week.
  • He hasn't been feeling well lately.
  • The system has been lagging since the update.
  • You have been working too hard recently.
  • The team has been making great progress this sprint.
  • I have been learning React for three months.
  • She has been living in London for a year.
  • We have been using this library since version 1.0.

7.title: Past Perfect
7.content:
The Past Perfect is the 'past of the past'. It is used to show that one action happened before another action in the past. It clarifies the sequence of events.

Structure:

Subject + had + Past Participle

Examples:

  • When I arrived, the meeting had already started.
  • She realized she had forgotten her laptop.
  • We had tested the code before we deployed it.
  • The server crashed because someone had deleted the config file.
  • He had never seen such messy code before that job.
  • By the time they fixed the bug, the users had already complained.
  • I didn't have any money because I had lost my wallet.

8.title: First Conditional
8.content:
The First Conditional is used to talk about real and possible future situations. It describes a likely result if a certain condition is met.

Structure:

If + Present Simple, ... will + Base Verb

Examples:

  • If we finish early, we will deploy the update.
  • If the server goes down, I will call you immediately.
  • You will miss the deadline if you don't start now.
  • She will be late if the train is delayed.
  • If I have time later, I 'll call you.
  • Will you help me if I need it?

9.title: Second Conditional
9.content:
The Second Conditional is used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present or future. It describes an imaginary result for an unreal condition.

Structure:

If + Past Simple, ... would + Base Verb

Examples:

  • If I had more time, I would refactor this module.
  • If we had the budget, we would hire another developer.
  • What would you do if you were the project manager?
  • If I were you, I would take the job.
  • Morale would improve if the company gave everyone a bonus.
  • We would travel more if we didn't have kids.

10.title: Third Conditional
10.content:
The Third Conditional is used to talk about hypothetical situations in the past. It describes an imaginary result for a past condition that did not happen. It's often used to express regret.

Structure:

If + Past Perfect, ... would have + Past Participle

Examples:

  • If I had known about the bug, I would have fixed it.
  • If we had tested it better, the system would not have crashed.
  • They would have finished on time if the requirements hadn't changed.
  • If you had told me, I would have helped you.
  • She wouldn't have been so tired if she had gone to bed earlier.
  • Would you have accepted the offer if they had offered more money?

11.title: Modal Perfects
11.content:
Modal Perfects are used to look back at the past and express regret, deduction, or lost opportunities. We have simplified this guide to focus on the structure and clear patterns.

Structure:

Subject + Modal + have + Past Participle

1. Should Have (Regret / Mistake)

Something was a good idea, but it didn't happen.

  • I should have saved the file earlier.
  • You should have told me about the bug.
  • We should have tested the backup.
  • He shouldn't have deleted the database.
  • They shouldn't have deployed on a Friday.

2. Could Have (Possibility / Ability)

It was possible in the past, but it didn't happen.

  • We could have fixed it, but we ran out of time.
  • You could have lost all your data!
  • She could have been the team lead.
  • I couldn't have done it without you.
  • They could have used a different API.

3. Must Have (Logical Deduction)

We are 99% sure something happened based on evidence.

  • The server is down. It must have crashed.
  • He isn't here. He must have forgotten the meeting.
  • The code works now. You must have fixed the error.
  • She must have misunderstood the requirements.
  • Someone must have changed the password.

4. Would Have (Hypothetical Result)

The result of a condition that didn't happen (3rd Conditional).

  • I would have called you, but I had no signal.
  • We would have finished if the internet hadn't died.
  • She would have accepted the offer.
  • They wouldn't have noticed the bug.
  • Would you have waited for me?

12.title: The Passive Voice
12.content:
The Passive Voice is used when the focus is on the action or the receiver of the action, not on the person who performs it (the agent). It is very common in technical and formal writing.

When to Use:

  • When the agent (doer) is unknown. (e.g., 'The server was hacked.')
  • When the agent is irrelevant. (e.g., 'The component is rendered.')
  • When you want to be formal and impersonal. (e.g., 'It is recommended that...')

Structure:

Receiver + be (conjugated) + Past Participle + (by Agent)

Examples:

  • The new feature was implemented last week.
  • The server is being restarted right now.
  • This report must be finished by tomorrow.
  • The data has been retrieved successfully.
  • The old code will be refactored by the senior developer.

13.title: Gerunds (-ing) vs. Infinitives (to + verb)
13.content:
Whether you use a gerund or an infinitive after a verb depends on the first verb. There is no logical rule for this; you must memorize which group the verb belongs to.

Group A: Verbs followed by Gerunds (-ing)

avoid, enjoy, finish, suggest, mind, keep, consider, recommend, discuss, miss

  • We should avoid deploying on Fridays.
  • She suggested using a different library.
  • I finished writing the tests.
  • Please keep monitoring the logs.
  • He doesn't mind helping you.

Group B: Verbs followed by Infinitives (to + verb)

want, need, decide, hope, plan, agree, promise, afford, learn, refuse

  • I decided to refactor the code.
  • We need to update the database.
  • They plan to launch next week.
  • She hopes to finish by 5 PM.
  • The client agreed to extend the deadline.

14.title: Gerunds after Prepositions
14.content:
Rule: If a verb follows a preposition (in, on, at, of, for, about, without, etc.), it must be a Gerund (-ing). Special attention is required for the word 'to', which can be either a preposition or part of an infinitive.

1. Standard Prepositions

Standard prepositions always require the -ing form.

  • He is good at solving problems.
  • I'm interested in learning React.
  • Thank you for helping me.
  • You can't leave without saying goodbye.
  • We talked about redesigning the website.
  • She is tired of working overtime.

2. Special Case: 'TO' as a Preposition

Usually, 'to' is followed by the base verb (infinitive). However, in certain fixed expressions, 'to' functions as a preposition and must be followed by a Gerund.

  • I'm looking forward to seeing you.
  • He is used to getting up early.
  • They object to changing the plan.
  • She is committed to improving the UI.
  • In addition to coding, he also does design.
  • I'm opposed to restarting the server now.

15.title: Used to vs. Be used to
15.content:
These two expressions look similar but are grammatically distinct and have completely different meanings. You must not mix them up.

1. Be used to (Accustomed to)

Subject + be (am/is/are) used to + Noun / Gerund (-ing)

Meaning: You are familiar with something; it is not new or strange to you.

  • I am used to working under pressure.
  • She is used to the cold weather in Canada.
  • They are finally used to using the new software.
  • He isn't used to getting up so early.
  • Are you used to driving on the left side?
  • We aren't used to spicy food yet.

2. Used to (Past Habit)

Subject + used to + Base Verb

Meaning: Something you did in the past but do not do anymore.

  • I used to live in New York.
  • She used to play the piano every day.
  • We didn't use to like vegetables. (Negative)
  • He used to have long hair.
  • Did you use to work here?
  • They used to be good friends.

16.title: Phrasal Verbs
16.content:
A Phrasal Verb combines a verb with a particle (preposition or adverb), creating a new meaning different from the original words. To help you distinguish them, we have alternated the highlight colors in the examples below.

Common Examples:

  • Run out of (Exhaust a supply)
    We have run out of coffee options.
  • Figure out (Understand/Solve)
    Can you figure out why the code failed?
  • Call off (Cancel)
    They had to call off the meeting.
  • Carry on (Continue)
    Please carry on with your work.
  • Back up (Support/Copy)
    Don't forget to back up your data.
  • Bring up (Mention a topic)
    Why did you bring up that issue now?
  • Turn down (Reject)
    She turned down the job offer.
  • Look forward to (Anticipate with pleasure)
    I look forward to hearing from you.
  • Put off (Postpone)
    We shouldn't put off the decision any longer.
  • Show up (Arrive/Appear)
    He didn't show up for the interview.
  • Get along (Have a good relationship)
    I get along well with my teammates.
  • Catch up (Reach the same level)
    I need to work late to catch up.

17.title: False Friends
17.content:
False Friends are words in two languages that look or sound similar but have different meanings. They are a common source of mistakes for native Spanish speakers.

Common Examples:

  • Actually (EN: in fact, really) ≠ 'Actualmente' (ES: currently)
  • Assist (EN: to help) ≠ 'Asistir' (ES: to attend)
  • Attend (EN: to be present at) ≠ 'Atender' (ES: to help, to serve)
  • Library (EN: biblioteca) ≠ 'Librería' (ES: bookstore)
  • Success (EN: éxito) ≠ 'Suceso' (ES: event)
  • Realize (EN: to become aware) ≠ 'Realizar' (ES: to carry out, to do)
  • Sensible (EN: practical, reasonable) ≠ 'Sensible' (ES: sensitive)
  • Fabric (EN: tela) ≠ 'Fábrica' (ES: factory)
  • Resume (EN: to continue) ≠ 'Resumir' (ES: to summarize)

18.title: Make vs. Do
18.content:
While both verbs relate to actions, they are not interchangeable. To make the distinction clearer, we have color-coded the examples: DO (Tasks/Actions) is in Cyan, and MAKE (Creating/Producing) is in Green.

1. When to use DO

Use DO for general activities, work, jobs, and obligations. It implies performing an action, not creating a physical object.

  • We need to do business with that new client.
  • Could you do me a favor and review this code?
  • I have to do the laundry this afternoon.
  • She always encourages me to do my best.
  • You should do some research before the meeting.
  • He did a good job on the presentation.
  • I have nothing to do this weekend.
  • They often do exercises in the morning.

2. When to use MAKE

Use MAKE for constructing, building, creating, or producing something new (a plan, a sound, a decision, a physical object).

  • The team needs to make a decision by Friday.
  • He was asked to make a suggestion.
  • I have to make a phone call before we start.
  • Try not to make a mistake in the final report.
  • This new feature will make a big difference.
  • She made a good point in the meeting.
  • Can you make an exception for this case?
  • We need to make a plan for the launch.

19.title: Modal Verbs: Future Equivalents
19.content:
Modals like can, must, and may do not have a future tense. To express these concepts in the future, we use substitute phrases with 'will'.

Structure:

Can → will be able to
Must → will have to
Allowed → will be allowed to

Examples:

  • Tomorrow, we will be able to access the new server.
  • You will have to reset your password soon.
  • She won't be able to attend the meeting next week.
  • When will I be able to download the file?
  • If the test fails, we will have to rewrite the code.
  • Users won't be allowed to view this page without admin rights.
  • Hopefully, they will be able to fix it by tomorrow.

20.title: Possessive Nouns ('s)
20.content:
Add 's to singular nouns. Add only ' to plural nouns ending in 's'.

Examples:

  • This is John's car.
  • The cat's toy is under the sofa.
  • My parents' house is big. (Plural)
  • The children's park. (Irregular plural)
  • James's (or James') bag.
  • The company's policy.
  • Where is the men's room?
  • I need my boss's approval.

21.title: Prepositions of Time: In, On, At
21.content:
Prepositions of time are strictly defined by the length or specificity of the time period. Think of it as a funnel: IN (General/Large), ON (Specific Days), AT (Precise Moments).

AT (Precise)

Specific clock times, holidays (the period), and standard fixed expressions.

  • At 5:00 PM
  • At noon / At midnight
  • At lunchtime
  • At sunrise
  • At Christmas (the season)
  • At night (Exception)
  • At the moment

ON (Days/Dates)

Specific days of the week, full dates, and special calendar days.

  • On Monday
  • On Friday morning
  • On July 4th
  • On New Year's Eve
  • On my birthday
  • On the weekend (US)
  • On weekdays

IN (Periods)

Months, years, seasons, centuries, and parts of the day.

  • In July
  • In 2024
  • In the 90s
  • In the 21st century
  • In summer
  • In the morning
  • In the future

22.title: Prepositions of Place: In, On, At (Physical Spaces)
22.content:
These prepositions refer to strictly physical locations. Use IN for 3D enclosed spaces, ON for 2D physical surfaces, and AT for specific 1D points, addresses, or events.

1. IN (Enclosed Spaces & Areas)

Used when someone or something is inside a physical container, room, building, or geographical area (cities, countries).

  • I left my laptop in the office.
  • The physical servers are located in the basement.
  • Our company is headquartered in London.
  • Keep the spare cables in that box.
  • She is waiting in the meeting room.
  • He locked himself in the car.

2. ON (Physical Surfaces)

Used when something is physically touching or resting on top of a surface, floor, or wall.

  • Leave the printed report on the desk.
  • We drew the architecture diagram on the whiteboard.
  • The IT department is on the second floor.
  • Please don't put your coffee on the server rack.
  • There is a strange mark on the wall.
  • I dropped my phone on the floor.

3. AT (Specific Points & Events)

Used to designate a highly specific location, an exact address, a destination, or a public event.

  • I will meet you at the entrance.
  • He is currently sitting at his desk.
  • They arrived at the data center early.
  • We presented the project at the tech conference.
  • Our office is located at 123 Main Street.
  • She is waiting at the bus stop.

23.title: Adjective vs. Adverb
23.content:
Adjectives describe nouns (people, things, places). Adverbs describe verbs (how an action is done), other adjectives, or whole sentences. Adverbs often end in -ly.

Structure:

[Subject] + [Verb] + Adjective
[Subject] + [Verb] + Adverb

Examples:

  • She is a quick learner.
  • She learns quickly.
  • The code is bad.
  • The code runs badly.
  • He is a careful driver.
  • He drives carefully.
  • This is an extremely important update.
  • He is a good developer.
  • He codes well.
  • It is a fast connection.
  • It loads fast.

24.title: Adverbs of Time: Still, Yet, Anymore & No Longer
24.content:
These four adverbs describe the continuity or cessation of an action. Choosing the right one depends on whether the action is ongoing, expected, or has stopped.

1. STILL (Continuity)

Used for actions that are ongoing and haven't stopped. Usually placed in the middle of the sentence.

  • The server is still running the migration.
  • Are you still working on that Jira ticket?
  • The bug still appears after the update.
  • We are still waiting for the client's approval.
  • It is midnight and the team is still coding.
  • Do you still need help with the CSS?

2. YET (Expectation)

Used in negative sentences or questions for actions that haven't happened but are expected. Usually placed at the end.

  • The deployment hasn't finished yet.
  • Has the script executed yet?
  • We don't have a fix for the login error yet.
  • Is the new version available yet?
  • I haven't received the API keys yet.
  • Is it time for the meeting yet?

3. ANYMORE & NO LONGER (Cessation)

Used for actions that happened in the past but have stopped. Anymore is standard/informal (at the end); No longer is formal (in the middle).

  • The legacy app isn't supported anymore.
  • We no longer require the old database credentials.
  • I don't use Internet Explorer anymore.
  • The system no longer allows duplicate entries.
  • She doesn't work in the DevOps department anymore.
  • There are no longer any errors in the production logs.

25.title: So vs. Such
25.content:
Both words are intensifiers used to add emphasis. The choice depends on the grammatical structure that follows.

1. SO (Adjective/Adverb Focus)

So + Adjective / Adverb

  • The test was so hard.
  • He drives so fast.
  • I was so happy to see you!
  • Why are you so angry?
  • The server is so slow today.
  • She speaks so quietly.

2. SUCH (Noun Focus)

Such + (a/an) + (Adj) + Noun

  • It was such a hard test.
  • It is such a nice day!
  • They are such friendly people.
  • I've never seen such messy code.
  • It was such an expensive mistake.
  • She has such great ideas.

26.title: Ago vs. For
26.content:
Both words relate to time, but they describe different concepts: a point in the past versus a span of time.

1. AGO (A Point in Time)

Used with the Past Simple to say how far back from now an event happened.

  • I arrived ten minutes ago.
  • We started the project two years ago.
  • He left an hour ago.
  • Dinosaurs lived millions of years ago.
  • She called me a few days ago.
  • I graduated three years ago.

2. FOR (A Duration of Time)

Used to describe the length or period of an action. It can be used with any tense.

  • I have waited for ten minutes.
  • We have worked on this for two years.
  • He slept for eight hours.
  • I am going away for the weekend.
  • They have been coding for five hours straight.
  • She lived in London for six months.

27.title: Comparatives and Superlatives
27.content:
We use comparatives to compare two things and superlatives to compare three or more things (or one thing against a whole group).

1. Comparatives (2 items)

Short: Adj + -er + than
Long: more + Adj + than

  • This API is faster than the old one.
  • Python is easier to learn than C++.
  • The new server is more powerful than the previous one.
  • Cloud storage is usually cheaper than maintaining local servers.
  • Today is hotter than yesterday.
  • My code is messier than yours.

2. Superlatives (3+ items / Group)

Short: the + Adj + -est
Long: the + most + Adj

  • This is the most difficult task in the project.
  • That was the worst bug I have ever seen. (Irregular)
  • React is the most used library right now.
  • Please choose the most efficient algorithm.
  • The furthest node is offline.
  • He is the best developer on the team. (Irregular)

28.title: Adjective Order
28.content:
In English, multiple adjectives must follow a specific sequence before a noun to sound natural.

Structure:

[Opinion] [Size] [Age] [Shape] [Color] [Origin] [Material] [Purpose] + Noun

Examples:

  • A lovely old red car.
  • A big square wooden table.
  • A beautiful Italian leather jacket.
  • A small black plastic bag.
  • An expensive new German sports car.
  • A delicious hot vegetable soup.
  • The ugly large round blue vase.
  • My favorite old English paper book.
  • A tiny ancient Greek gold coin.
  • A useful long metal measuring tape.
  • Those smart little brown leather shoes.
  • An amazing huge modern glass building.

29.title: Countable vs. Uncountable Nouns
29.content:
Understanding the distinction between Countable and Uncountable nouns is fundamental because it dictates which quantifiers and verbs you must use.

1. Countable Nouns (Individual Units)

Things you can count using numbers. They have both singular and plural forms.

Structure:

Many / A few / A large number of + [Plural Noun]

  • How many bugs did you find?
  • We have a few options to consider.
  • There are a large number of servers in the cluster.
  • I need several tickets to be closed.
  • Only one developer is available.
  • The number of products increased this month.
  • We have fewer users than last year.

2. Uncountable Nouns (Mass / Abstract)

Things seen as a whole or mass that cannot be separated into discrete units (e.g., data, code, progress, advice). They are always singular.

Structure:

Much / A little / A large amount of + [Singular Noun]

  • How much data was processed?
  • We made a little progress on the feature.
  • There is a large amount of traffic on the network.
  • I need some advice on this implementation.
  • The amount of work is overwhelming.
  • We have less information than we expected.

3. Critical Rule: The Article "A/An"

The article "A" or "An" literally means "One". Therefore, you can NEVER use it with uncountable nouns.

  • [Correct]: It's just progress.
  • ~Incorrect~: It's just ~a progress~.
  • [Correct]: We need software.
  • ~Incorrect~: We need ~a software~.
  • [Correct]: Can you give me advice?
  • ~Incorrect~: Can you give me ~an advice~?

4. Mixed Quantifiers (Both Cases)

These flexible words work with both types. Keep nouns plural for countables and singular for uncountables.

Some / Any / A lot of / Plenty of / More / Most / Enough / No

  • I have a lot of tickets to review. (Countable)
  • We have a lot of work pending. (Uncountable)
  • Are there any logs available? (Countable)
  • Is there any documentation for this API? (Uncountable)
  • We need more resources. (Countable)
  • I need more time. (Uncountable)
  • Most developers prefer dark mode. (Countable)
  • Most of the budget was spent on AWS. (Uncountable)
  • We don't have enough units in stock. (Countable)
  • We don't have enough evidence yet. (Uncountable)

30.title: Articles: A/An vs. The
30.content:
A/An is for general/unknown things (one of many). The is for specific/known things (the only one, or one mentioned before).

Examples:

  • I need a pen. (Any pen will do)
  • I need the pen that is on your desk. (Specific)
  • She bought a new car.
  • The car she bought is red.
  • Can I ask a question?
  • What is the answer to question 5?
  • He is an engineer.
  • The sun is hot. (Unique)
  • We have a problem with the server.

31.title: Zero Article (No Article)
31.content:
Do not use 'the' for general plural nouns, abstract nouns, names of people/cities/countries (mostly), or meals.

Examples:

  • Dogs are friendly. (All dogs)
  • I love music. (Abstract)
  • He lives in Japan.
  • She speaks English.
  • We are having lunch.
  • Money doesn't buy happiness.
  • President Smith is speaking.
  • I go to school by bus.

32.title: Too vs. Enough
32.content:
Too = More than necessary (Negative). Enough = Sufficient (Positive). Note the position.

Structure:

Too + Adjective
Adjective + Enough
Enough + Noun

Examples:

  • The coffee is too hot. I can't drink it.
  • He isn't old enough to drive.
  • I don't have enough time.
  • You are working too slowly.
  • This laptop is too expensive.
  • Is the room warm enough?
  • There are too many bugs in this code.
  • We have enough developers for the project.

33.title: Connectors of Contrast
33.content:
These words connect contrasting ideas. The grammar rules for what follows the connector are strict.

Group 1: Followed by a Clause (Subject + Verb)

Although / Even though / While / Whereas + [Subject + Verb]

  • Although the code works, it is not efficient.
  • Even though we tested it, a bug appeared.
  • He likes Java, whereas I prefer Python.
  • While the migration is complex, it is necessary.

Group 2: Followed by a Noun or Gerund (-ing)

Despite / In spite of + [Noun / Verb-ing]

  • Despite the delay, we launched on time.
  • In spite of working late, we didn't finish.
  • They continued despite the errors.

Group 3: Connectors between Sentences

Sentence. However / Nevertheless, Sentence.

  • The plan is good. However, we lack resources.
  • The server crashed. Nevertheless, no data was lost.
  • It was expensive. On the other hand, the quality is top-notch.

34.title: Relative Clauses (who, which, that)
34.content:
Relative clauses add information about a noun. The choice of pronoun depends on whether we are talking about a person or a thing.

The Pronouns:

  • Who: For people.
  • Which: For things or animals.
  • That: For people or things (informal/standard).
  • Whose: For possession.

Examples:

  • The developer who wrote this code is a genius.
  • This is the error which caused the crash.
  • I met a woman who works at Microsoft.
  • Where is the file that was on my desktop?
  • The customer whose account was suspended called support.
  • We need a tool which can handle large datasets.
  • He is the one that told me about the job.
  • Companies that ignore security often get hacked.

35.title: Question Tags
35.content:
Short questions at the end of sentences to ask for confirmation. Positive sentence → Negative tag. Negative sentence → Positive tag.

Examples:

  • You are a student, aren't you?
  • He isn't coming, is he?
  • She works here, doesn't she?
  • They didn't finish, did they?
  • You have eaten, haven't you?
  • I am right, aren't I? (Irregular)
  • Let's go, shall we? (Irregular)
  • Sit down, will you? (Imperative)

36.title: Get + Adjective
36.content:
The verb get is frequently used with an adjective to express a change of state. It means 'to become' or 'to start to be'. It implies a process.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Adjective

Examples:

  • I am getting tired of these repetitive tasks.
  • The situation got complicated very quickly.
  • Don't get angry; it's just a minor issue.
  • It is getting late; we should wrap up.
  • He got sick right before the presentation.
  • They are getting ready for the deployment.
  • My coffee has gotten cold.
  • You will get used to the new workflow soon.
  • The user got confused by the new interface.
  • If you don't save, your work might get lost.
  • It gets dark very early in winter.
  • She got excited when she saw the results.

37.title: Had Better ('d better)
37.content:
Had better is a strong modal expression used to give advice or warnings. It implies that there will be a negative consequence or problem if the advice is not followed.

Important: Although the form is 'had' (past), the meaning refers to the immediate future. It is NOT past tense.

Structure:

Subject + had better + Base Verb

In conversation, 'had' is almost always contracted to 'd (e.g., You'd better...).

Examples:

  • You'd better leave now or you'll miss the train.
  • We'd better save the file before the program crashes.
  • He'd better apologize to the client immediately.
  • You'd better put on a coat; it's freezing outside.
  • I'd better get back to work.
  • They'd better have a good reason for this delay.
  • (Negative) You'd better not tell anyone about this.
  • (Negative) She'd better not forget the meeting time.
  • (Negative) We'd better not wake the baby.
  • (Full Form) You had better listen carefully.
  • (Full Form) He had better fix that bug today.
  • (Negative) I'd better not drink any more coffee.

38.title: Be Supposed To
38.content:
Used for obligations, expectations, or general beliefs. It often implies the reality is different.

Examples:

  • I am supposed to be at work now.
  • The weather is supposed to be sunny today.
  • You aren't supposed to smoke here.
  • The train was supposed to arrive an hour ago.
  • What am I supposed to do?
  • This movie is supposed to be really good.

39.title: Causative Verbs (make, let, have, get)
39.content:
Causative verbs express that a Subject (person, thing, or event) causes a change or an action to happen to an Object. The grammar structure is strictly defined by the verb used.

1. MAKE (Forced Results / Automatic Causes)

Used when something or someone forces a result. This includes technical errors or emotional reactions.

[Subject] + make + [Object] + Base Verb

  • The bug made the system crash.
  • That joke made me laugh.
  • Heavy traffic made him arrive late.
  • The manager made us rewrite the documentation.
  • The sad movie made her cry.
  • Bad configuration made the server fail.

2. LET (Permission / Allowance)

Used when a subject permits an action or allows a process to happen.

[Subject] + let + [Object] + Base Verb

  • The firewall lets the data pass.
  • My boss let me leave early yesterday.
  • Don't let the battery run out.
  • The new update lets users customize the UI.
  • Please let me know if you need help.
  • She let the dog go outside.

3. HAVE (Responsibility / Assignment)

Used when you give someone a task or arrange for a process to happen.

[Subject] + have + [Object] + Base Verb

  • I'll have my assistant call you.
  • Please have the team test the new build.
  • The teacher had the students submit their essays.
  • We had the technician repair the router.
  • She had the script execute every hour.
  • I had the developer fix the CSS.

4. GET (Persuasion / Effort / Achievement)

Used when effort is required to produce a result. Note: This is the only causative verb that requires 'to'.

[Subject] + get + [Object] + to + Verb

  • I finally got the code to work correctly.
  • How did you get the client to sign?
  • She got him to join the volunteer group.
  • We need to get the server to respond faster.
  • I can't get my kids to clean their room.
  • Try to get the application to load the cache.

40.title: Wish / If Only
40.content:
We use wish or if only to talk about things we want to be different. The verb tense 'shifts back' into the past.

Structure:

Present Wish → Use Past Simple
Past Regret → Use Past Perfect

Examples:

  • I wish I had more time. (I don't have time)
  • She wishes she knew Python. (She doesn't know it)
  • If only I wasn't so busy today.
  • I wish the server was faster.
  • (Regret) I wish I hadn't deleted that file.
  • (Regret) If only we had tested it before launch.
  • (Regret) He wishes he had taken the job offer.
  • I wish it would stop raining. (Complaint about future/now)

41.title: Would Rather ('d rather)
41.content:
Used to express a specific preference in a given situation. It is always followed by the base verb.

Structure:

Subject + 'd rather + Base Verb

Examples:

  • I'd rather stay home tonight.
  • We'd rather not go out in the rain.
  • Would you rather have coffee?
  • They'd rather finish the task tomorrow.
  • He'd rather use Python.
  • I'd rather wait here.

Using 'Than' for Comparison:

When comparing two actions, the verb after than must also remain in the base form (infinitive without 'to'). Never use the gerund (-ing) form.

Structure:

'd rather + Verb A + than + Verb B

Examples:

  • She'd rather read a book than watch TV.
  • I'd rather walk than take the bus.
  • They'd rather fail than cheat.
  • He'd rather quit than work for them.
  • I'd rather cook at home than eat out.
  • We'd rather buy it than rent it.

42.title: Words ending in -ever
42.content:
Indicate 'it doesn't matter' or 'any'.

Examples:

  • Whatever you do, don't give up.
  • You can go wherever you want.
  • Call me whenever you need help.
  • Whoever broke the vase must pay for it.
  • I will buy whichever one is cheaper.
  • However you try to fix it, it won't work.
  • Choose whichever seat you like.

43.title: As long as / Provided that
43.content:
Conditionals meaning 'if' or 'on the condition that'.

Examples:

  • You can borrow my car as long as you drive carefully.
  • Provided that you finish your work, you can leave early.
  • I don't care where we go as long as we are together.
  • He will sign the contract provided that the terms are clear.
  • As long as it doesn't rain, we will play.

44.title: Either/Or and Neither/Nor
44.content:
Used to pair alternatives. Either...or connects two positive choices. Neither...nor connects two negative choices.

Examples:

  • You can either call me or email me.
  • Neither John nor Peter was there.
  • I drink neither coffee nor tea.
  • We can use either React or Vue.
  • Either you finish it, or I will.
  • The solution was neither efficient nor scalable.
  • You must either stay or go.

45.title: Reported Speech: Statements
45.content:
Reported Speech is used to describe what someone said without using their exact words. The core rule is Backshifting: moving the verb tense one step into the past.

1. Present Simple → Past Simple

  • Direct: "The API is ready."
    Reported: He said the API was ready.
  • Direct: "I work here."
    Reported: She said she worked there.
  • Direct: "We like it."
    Reported: They said they liked it.

2. Present Continuous → Past Continuous

  • Direct: "I am testing it."
    Reported: He said he was testing it.
  • Direct: "It is running."
    Reported: She said it was running.
  • Direct: "We are waiting."
    Reported: They said they were waiting.

3. Past Simple & Present Perfect → Past Perfect

  • Direct: "I saw the bug."
    Reported: He said he had seen the bug.
  • Direct: "I have finished."
    Reported: She said she had finished.
  • Direct: "We pushed the code."
    Reported: They said they had pushed the code.

4. Future (Will) → Conditional (Would)

  • Direct: "I will call you."
    Reported: He said he would call me.
  • Direct: "It will fail."
    Reported: She said it would fail.
  • Direct: "We will help."
    Reported: They said they would help.

5. Modals (Can/May) → (Could/Might)

  • Direct: "I can solve it."
    Reported: He said he could solve it.
  • Direct: "It may rain."
    Reported: She said it might rain.
  • Direct: "You can leave."
    Reported: He said I could leave.

46.title: Reported Speech: Questions
46.content:
When reporting questions, the sentence structure changes from a question (with inversion) to a statement. The verb tense also 'shifts back' just like with statements.

Yes/No Questions:

Use 'if' or 'whether'. The word order becomes: Subject + Verb.

  • Direct: 'Are you finished?'
    → Reported: He asked if I was finished.
  • Direct: 'Does it have a cache?'
    → Reported: She asked whether it had a cache.
  • Direct: 'Have you pushed the changes?'
    → Reported: They asked if I had pushed the changes.

Wh- Questions:

Use the original question word (what, where, when, why, how). The word order also becomes: Subject + Verb.

  • Direct: 'Where is the file?'
    → Reported: She asked where the file was.
  • Direct: 'What did you change?'
    → Reported: He asked what I had changed.
  • Direct: 'When will the meeting start?'
    → Reported: They asked when the meeting would start.

47.title: Infinitive of Purpose
47.content:
The Infinitive of Purpose is used to explain the reason or intention behind an action. It answers the question 'Why?'.

Structure:

[Action Verb] + to + Base Verb

Examples:

  • I went to the store to buy milk.
  • She called to invite me to the party.
  • He is studying hard to pass the exam.
  • We use git to manage versions.
  • Click here to download the file.
  • She keeps practicing to improve her pronunciation.

Intention (To) vs. Activity (-ing)

We use the infinitive to focus on the intended result. Using a gerund usually focuses on the activity itself as a noun.

  • I work to earn money. (My goal is the money)
  • I enjoy working. (I like the activity itself)
  • He stopped to smoke. (His intention was to have a cigarette)
  • He stopped smoking. (He quit the activity forever)

48.title: Singular 'They'
48.content:
Used when the gender of the person is unknown, irrelevant, or concealed. It uses plural verbs.

Examples:

  • If a customer calls, tell them I'm busy.
  • Someone left their umbrella here.
  • Who was that? I didn't recognize them.
  • Every student should do their best.
  • Nobody thinks they will fail.
  • Ask the teacher what they think.

49.title: Prepositions: For vs. Of
49.content:
For indicates purpose, beneficiary, or duration. Of indicates possession, content, or part of a group.

Examples (FOR):

  • This gift is for you.
  • I bought a new monitor for gaming.
  • We are waiting for the bus.
  • I spoke for 20 minutes.

Examples (OF):

  • The color of the car is blue.
  • She is a friend of mine.
  • I drank a cup of coffee.
  • It is the first day of the month.

50.title: Identifying the Subject
50.content:
To master questions, you must redefine the SUBJECT. It is not always a person or a 'living thing'; it is simply the topic or the entity that performs the action or exists in a state.

Understanding and recognizing the subject is fundamental to correctly applying the rules of "Standard Questions (Known Subject)".

Master Structure:

(Wh- word) + Verb/Aux + Subject + [Verb Block] + [Object/Complement]?

1. Pronouns & Personal Names

The most common subjects. They refer to known people, groups, or established entities using It (singular) and They (plural for people and things).

  • Are you right?
  • Where does he work?
  • When did Andres call?
  • When did it happen?
  • Where did they go? (Referring to files or servers)
  • Does it have enough RAM?

2. Demonstratives (This, That, These, Those)

These words 'point' to an object or a situation, making them the subject of the inquiry.

  • Who does this belong to?
  • Why does that matter?
  • How do these work?
  • Does this have a cache?
  • Is that true?
  • When did this happen?

3. Objects and Tools as Subjects

Any inanimate entity that 'performs' a failure, a process, or exists in a state.

  • Is the server down?
  • Why did the deployment fail?
  • Does this ticket have criteria?
  • How does the script run?
  • Will the update restart the PC?
  • Has the database connected?

4. Abstract Concepts as Subjects

Ideas, names, or feelings that act as the primary focus of the sentence.

  • Will the nickname stick to him?
  • How did the error occur?
  • Does change bother you?
  • Is simplicity important?
  • Where did the conversation go?

52.title: Transitive, Intransitive & Prepositional Verbs
52.content:
Transitive verbs pass the action directly to an object. Intransitive verbs do not pass action to an object. A major challenge for Spanish speakers is knowing when to use the preposition 'to'.

1. Direct Transitive (NO 'TO')

These verbs connect directly to the object. Even if you say 'a' in Spanish (Contactar a alguien), you must not use 'to' in English.

  • Call him immediately. (~Call to him~)
  • Please contact the manager. (~Contact to~)
  • Answer the question. (~Answer to~)
  • I will visit my clients tomorrow.
  • They discussed the problem. (~Discussed about~)
  • The software controls the hardware.

2. Prepositional Verbs (REQUIRE 'TO')

These verbs technically function as intransitive in this context; they need the bridge 'to' to connect to the object. Omitting it is a grammatical error.

  • I am listening to the podcast. (~Listening the podcast~)
  • Can you explain this to me? (Explain ALWAYS needs 'to' for the person).
  • This laptop belongs to the company.
  • I need to talk to you regarding the bug.
  • She replied to the email.
  • You must adapt to the changes.

3. Pure Intransitive (NO Object)

These verbs are complete actions in themselves. They do not need an object to make sense.

  • The baby cried.
  • The sun rose at 6 AM.
  • We arrived late.
  • It happened yesterday.
  • The server died (crashed).

53.title: Verbs of Motion (Manner vs. Path)
53.content:
Manner verbs (go, walk, run) need 'to'. Path verbs (enter, reach, approach) do NOT use 'to'.

Examples:

  • I went to the park.
  • I walked to the station.
  • She entered the room. (No 'to')
  • We reached our destination. (No 'to')
  • He approached the building.
  • They arrived at the hotel. (Exception)
  • Don't go into the cave.

54.title: Reflexive Pronouns
54.content:
Used when the Subject and Object are the same person.

Examples:

  • I cut myself while cooking.
  • He is looking at himself in the mirror.
  • She taught herself Spanish.
  • We enjoyed ourselves at the party.
  • The computer turned itself off.
  • Help yourself to some food.
  • They blame themselves for the mistake.

55.title: Future: Will vs. Going To
55.content:
Both forms talk about the future, but the choice depends on when you made the decision or what evidence you have right now.

1. Will (Spontaneous & Predictions)

Use Will for decisions made at the moment of speaking (spontaneous), promises, or predictions without physical evidence (beliefs).

  • The phone is ringing. I'll answer it. (Instant decision)
  • I'll help you with that report right now. (Offer)
  • Don't worry, I won't tell anyone. (Promise)
  • I think cars will fly in 2050. (Belief)
  • I'll have the chicken, please. (Ordering food)
  • Maybe I'll stay home tonight. (Uncertainty)

2. Going To (Plans & Evidence)

Use Going To for plans made before speaking (intentions) or predictions based on visible evidence.

  • I'm going to visit my parents this weekend. (Planned)
  • We are going to launch the new site on Friday. (Scheduled)
  • Look at those dark clouds! It's going to rain. (Evidence)
  • She is going to have a baby. (Evidence)
  • I bought my ticket. I'm going to fly to Paris. (Preparation done)
  • Watch out! You're going to fall! (Immediate evidence)

56.title: Past Perfect Continuous
56.content:
Used for an action that was happening for a period of time before another action in the past occurred. It emphasizes the duration.

Structure:

Subject + had been + Verb-ing

Examples:

  • I had been working for 10 hours when I finally quit.
  • She was tired because she had been running.
  • They had been trying to fix the bug for days before they found the solution.
  • It had been raining all night, so the ground was wet.
  • How long had you been waiting before the bus arrived?
  • We had been using that software for years before we switched.
  • He had been living in London when the war started.

57.title: Past Habits: 'Used to' vs. 'Would'
57.content:
Both used to and would are used to talk about repeated actions or habits in the past that are no longer true now. However, they have one very important difference.

1. Used to (Actions & States)

Used to is the safest option. It can describe past actions (run, play, smoke) AND past states (be, have, live, love).

  • I used to live in Paris. (State)
  • She used to have long hair. (State)
  • We used to go camping. (Action)

2. Would (Actions ONLY)

Would is only for past actions. It cannot be used for states. It is often used in stories to create a nostalgic tone.

  • Every summer, we would visit the lake. (Action)
  • My dad would always read to me. (Action)
  • I would have a car. (Incorrect - State)

10 Examples in Context:

  • (Nostalgia) Grandpa would sit there for hours.
  • (State) I used to be very shy.
  • (Habit) She would call me every Sunday.
  • (State) There used to be a park here.
  • (Comparison) I used to smoke, but I quit.
  • (Story) The dog would wait by the door.
  • (Negative) He didn't use to like vegetables.
  • (State) We used to own a house.
  • (Action) They would play soccer until dark.
  • (Question) Did you use to work here?

59.title: Basic Modal Verbs
59.content:
Modal Verbs express ability, permission, obligation, advice, or possibility. They are auxiliary verbs that always accompany a base verb (e.g., 'go', 'do', 'be') and they do not change form for the subject (no '-s' for third person).

Structure:

Subject + modal + Base Verb

Common Modals:

  • Can: (Ability, Permission)
    I can fix this bug right now.
    You can't deploy this until it's tested.
  • Could: (Past Ability, Polite Request)
    Could you help me with this file?
    I couldn't access the server yesterday.
  • May: (Formal Permission, Possibility)
    This may cause a side effect we haven't seen.
    You may not leave until the process is complete.
  • Might: (Possibility)
    We might need to refactor this class later.
    It might not be the best solution, but it works.
  • Must: (Strong Obligation, Prohibition)
    You must update the documentation.
    You mustn't push code directly to the main branch.
  • Should: (Advice, Expectation)
    You should test your code before committing.
    We shouldn't wait until the last minute.
  • Ought to: (Moral Obligation/Advice)
    You ought to apologize. (Note: Always uses 'to')
  • Will: (Future Action, Willingness)
    I'll call you back in five minutes.
    The system won't accept the new password.
  • Would: (Polite Request, Hypothetical)
    Would you mind sending me the file?
    I wouldn't do that if I were you.

60.title: Imperative Sentences
60.content:
Used for orders, instructions, or advice. No subject is used.

Examples:

  • Open the door.
  • Don't touch that!
  • Be quiet.
  • Turn left at the corner.
  • Please help me.
  • Have a nice day.
  • Click the save button.

61.title: Existential 'There'
61.content:
We use There + Be to say that something exists for the first time in a conversation. It should not be confused with 'It', which refers to a specific noun already mentioned.

1. There + To Be (Standard)

There + is / are / was / were + Noun

  • There is a bug in the code.
  • There are three open tickets.
  • There was a power outage last night.
  • There were many people at the demo.
  • Is there a way to revert the changes?
  • There isn't any space left on the disk.

2. There + Modal Verbs

There + modal + be + Noun

  • There must be a mistake in the configuration.
  • There might be a delay in the release.
  • There will be a meeting at 10 AM.
  • There should be an error message here.
  • There couldn't be a simpler solution.
  • Will there be any food at the event?

3. There + Verbs of Appearance

There + verb + to be + Noun

  • There seems to be a problem with the server.
  • There appears to be some confusion.
  • There used to be a park on this corner.
  • There tends to be heavy traffic on Mondays.
  • There happened to be a doctor in the building.
  • There needs to be more transparency.

62.title: Want/Need + Object + Infinitive
62.content:
Used when you want SOMEONE ELSE to do something.

Structure:

Subject + Want + Person + to + Verb

Examples:

  • I want you to clean your room.
  • She needs him to sign the document.
  • He asked me to help.
  • Do you want us to wait?
  • The teacher told the students to sit down.
  • I didn't expect them to arrive so early.

63.title: Noun Clauses (What... is...)
63.content:
Using a clause starting with 'What' as the subject for emphasis.

Examples:

  • What I need is a vacation.
  • What he said was true.
  • What happened is a mystery.
  • What you see is what you get.
  • What confuses me is the last step.
  • What I like about her is her honesty.
  • All I want is some peace and quiet.

64.title: Gerund as Subject
64.content:
A Gerund (-ing form) functions as a noun. When it acts as the main subject of a sentence, it is always treated as singular. This structure is more common than using an infinitive to start a sentence.

Structure:

Verb-ing + [Singular Verb] + ...

1. General Habits & Health

  • Smoking is prohibited in this area.
  • Exercising daily improves focus.
  • Eating healthy foods provides more energy.
  • Sleeping eight hours is essential for recovery.
  • Walking to work is a great way to stay active.
  • Reading before bed helps me relax.

2. Technology & Technical Processes

  • Coding in Python is very efficient.
  • Testing every edge case takes a lot of time.
  • Debugging legacy code can be frustrating.
  • Monitoring the server logs is a daily task.
  • Optimizing the database improved site speed.
  • Deploying on Friday is generally avoided.

3. Professional Skills & Education

  • Learning React requires knowledge of JavaScript.
  • Managing a large team is quite challenging.
  • Working remotely offers more flexibility.
  • Presenting data clearly is a vital skill.
  • Writing documentation ensures project continuity.
  • Negotiating contracts requires patience.

65.title: Zero Conditional
65.content:
The Zero Conditional is used for general truths, facts, and scientific laws. It describes a result that always happens if a condition is met.

Structure:

If/When + Present Simple, ... Present Simple

Examples:

  • If you click this button, it opens a modal.
  • If the server receives too many requests, it gets slow.
  • When a user enters the wrong password, the system shows an error message.
  • If water reaches 100 degrees Celsius, it boils.
  • Plants die if they don't get enough water.
  • When I have a lot of work, I get stressed.

67.title: 'How long has it been since...?'
67.content:
This structure is used to ask about the amount of time that has passed since a specific event in the past happened. It is a very common way to measure time elapsed.

Structure:

How long + has it been + since + Subject + Past Simple?

Examples:

  • How long has it been since we last met?
  • How long has it been since you visited your hometown?
  • How long has it been since he quit his job?
  • How long has it been since the server crashed?
  • How long has it been since you ate?
  • It has been two years since I saw her. (Answer)

68.title: Collective Nouns
68.content:
Collective nouns refer to a group of people or things. The verb agreement depends on the variety of English you are speaking.

The Rule: American vs. British

  • American English: Collective nouns are treated as Singular. The group acts as one unit.
    The team is winning.
  • British English: They can be Plural if focusing on individual members.
    The team are winning.

Examples (Standard American Usage):

  • The team is ready for the sprint. (Not 'are')
  • Our company has a strict security policy.
  • The government has released new regulations.
  • The committee decides on the budget today.
  • The staff is in a meeting.
  • The audience was very engaged during the demo.
  • The public needs to be informed.
  • The class starts at 9:00 AM.
  • A crowd was gathering outside.
  • My family lives in another city.

Important Exceptions (Always Plural):

  • The police are investigating the incident.
  • People are complaining about the bug.

69.title: Extreme (Non-Gradable) Adjectives
69.content:
Adjectives that mean 'very + adjective'. Use 'absolutely', not 'very'.

Examples:

  • Cold → Freezing
  • Hot → Boiling
  • Big → Huge / Enormous
  • Small → Tiny
  • Good → Amazing / Fantastic
  • Bad → Terrible / Awful
  • Tired → Exhausted
  • Hungry → Starving
  • Funny → Hilarious
  • Dirty → Filthy

70.title: Prepositional Adjectives
70.content:
Many adjectives must be followed by a specific preposition to be grammatically correct. These combinations (collocations) should be learned as fixed phrases, as the adjective dictates which preposition to use.

Structure:

... Adjective + Preposition

Examples:

  • I'm responsible for deploying the changes.
  • She is good at solving complex problems.
  • This component is similar to the old one.
  • Are you aware of the new security policy?
  • He is very interested in machine learning.
  • This method is different from the one we used before.
  • Don't be afraid of asking questions.

71.title: Separable Phrasal Verbs
71.content:
Some Phrasal Verbs are Separable. This means the object can separate the verb and the particle. The position depends on whether the object is a Noun or a Pronoun.

1. The Pronoun Rule (Mandatory Separation)

If the object is a Pronoun (it, him, her, them, us, me, you), it MUST go in the middle.

  • Turn down it. → Turn it down. (Correct)
  • Pick up him. → Pick him up.
  • Put away them. → Put them away.
  • Throw away it. → Throw it away.
  • Write down it. → Write it down.
  • Call back her. → Call her back.

2. The Noun Rule (Flexible)

If the object is a Noun (the light, the trash, John), it can go in the middle OR at the end. Both are correct.

  • Turn the light off. OR Turn off the light.
  • Pick John up. OR Pick up John.
  • Fill the form out. OR Fill out the form.
  • Look the word up. OR Look up the word.
  • Take your shoes off. OR Take off your shoes.
  • Clean the room up. OR Clean up the room.

72.title: Indefinite Pronouns
72.content:
Indefinite pronouns refer to people or things without saying exactly who or what they are. The most important rule is that they are grammatically singular.

The 'One Body' Rule

Words ending in -one, -body, or -thing always take a Singular Verb (is, has, does, wants, plays), just like 'He' or 'She'.

People (-one / -body)

  • Everyone is ready. (Not 'are')
  • Somebody is calling you.
  • Nobody knows the truth.
  • Anyone is welcome here.
  • Everyone has their own opinion.
  • No one likes to be rejected.

Things (-thing)

  • Everything is going well.
  • Something smells burning.
  • Nothing happened yesterday.
  • Is anything broken?
  • Everything looks perfect.
  • Nothing lasts forever.

73.title: Comparisons of Equality (as...as)
73.content:
Used to show two things are equal. In negative sentences ('not as...as'), it means the first thing is less than the second.

Structure:

as + Adj/Adv + as

Examples:

  • She is as tall as her brother.
  • This code is as efficient as the old one.
  • I can run as fast as you.
  • It is not as expensive as I thought.
  • Please come as soon as possible.
  • He doesn't work as hard as she does.
  • The movie wasn't as good as the book.

74.title: Inversion for Emphasis
74.content:
Formal structure using negative adverbs (Never, Rarely, Hardly) at the start. Invert Subject and Auxiliary.

Examples:

  • Never have I seen such a thing.
  • Rarely do we eat out.
  • Not only is he smart, but he is also kind.
  • Hardly had I arrived when the phone rang.
  • Little did he know about the surprise.
  • Under no circumstances should you open this door.

75.title: Cleft Sentences (It is... that...)
75.content:
Used to emphasize a specific part of the sentence.

Examples:

  • It was John who broke the window. (Not Peter)
  • It is rain that we need.
  • It was yesterday that I saw her.
  • It is your attitude that implies a problem.
  • It was in London that they met.
  • It was the dog that ate my homework.

76.title: Participle Adjectives (-ed vs. -ing)
76.content:
Adjectives ending in -ed describe how a person feels. Adjectives ending in -ing describe the cause of the feeling (the situation or object).

1. -ed Adjectives (Feelings)

  • I am bored because the talk is long.
  • She is excited about the new project.
  • He feels tired after working late.
  • We were confused by the instructions.
  • Are you interested in learning Python?
  • They felt frustrated by the slow internet.

2. -ing Adjectives (Causes)

  • The movie was very boring.
  • The news is very exciting.
  • This work is extremely tiring.
  • The documentation is confusing.
  • Machine learning is an interesting topic.
  • It was a frustrating experience for the team.

77.title: Agreement with 'So' and 'Too'
77.content:
Agreeing with positive statements.

Structure:

So + Aux + Subject
Subject + Aux + too

Examples:

  • I am happy. → So am I. / I am too.
  • She loves pizza. → So do I. / I do too.
  • He went home. → So did we. / We did too.
  • They can swim. → So can he. / He can too.
  • I have finished. → So have I. / I have too.
  • I will go. → So will she. / She will too.

78.title: Exclamations with 'What a' and 'How'
78.content:
To make exclamations, use What a/an... before a (adjective +) singular countable noun, and How... before an adjective or adverb.

Structure:

What a/an + (Adj) + Noun!
How + Adjective/Adverb!

Examples:

  • What a terrible bug!
  • What an elegant solution!
  • How inefficient this query is!
  • How quickly he works!

79.title: Prepositional Verbs (Common Combinations)
79.content:
Many English verbs require a specific preposition to connect to their object. These combinations are fixed and must be memorized. Using the wrong preposition (or none at all) is a common error.

Verbs + TO

  • Listen to the music.
  • Talk to your boss.
  • Speak to the team.
  • Belong to a group.
  • Apologize to someone.
  • Explain something to me.
  • Happen to the server.

Verbs + FOR

  • Wait for the bus.
  • Ask for help.
  • Look for your keys.
  • Pay for dinner.
  • Search for a solution.
  • Prepare for the meeting.
  • Apologize for the mistake.

Verbs + AT

  • Look at the board.
  • Laugh at a joke.
  • Smile at her.
  • Arrive at the airport.
  • Aim at the target.
  • Shout at someone (aggressively).

Verbs + ON / IN / WITH

  • Depend on the weather.
  • Rely on the backup.
  • Concentrate on the code.
  • Believe in yourself.
  • Succeed in fixing it.
  • Agree with a person.
  • Deal with the problem.

80.title: Preferences: Prefer vs. Would Prefer
80.content:
English distinguishes between general habits and specific choices in the moment.

1. PREFER (General Habits)

Used to talk about what you like in general. It usually compares two nouns or activities.

Structure:

Prefer + Noun/Gerund + to + Noun/Gerund

Examples:

  • I prefer coffee to tea.
  • She prefers running to swimming.
  • They prefer working from home.
  • We prefer Mac to Windows.
  • He prefers dogs to cats.
  • Most users prefer dark mode.

2. WOULD PREFER (Specific Situations)

Used for a choice right now or in a specific future event. It is more formal and always uses 'to'.

Structure:

'd prefer + to + Verb

Examples:

  • I'd prefer to stay home today.
  • Would you prefer to meet later?
  • We'd prefer not to discuss this yet.
  • She'd prefer to use a different tool.
  • Where would you prefer to sit?
  • I'd prefer to finish this now.

81.title: Impersonal Sentences
81.content:
In English, every sentence requires a subject. When there isn't a real person or thing doing the action, we use a 'dummy subject': usually It.

1. 'It' for Time, Weather, and Distance

  • It is 5 o'clock.
  • It is raining outside. (Not: 'Is raining')
  • It is cold today.
  • It is very late.
  • It is 10 kilometers to the city.
  • It takes 20 minutes to get there.

2. 'It' for General Opinions/Facts (Infinitive)

It is + Adjective + to + Verb

  • It is important to save your work frequently.
  • It is hard to learn a new language.
  • It is nice to meet you.
  • It is dangerous to drive fast.
  • It is easy to make a mistake.
  • It is impossible to finish by tomorrow.

3. 'They' for Indefinite People

Used when referring to people in general, or authorities.

  • They say that breakfast is the most important meal.
  • They sell fresh bread at that bakery.

82.title: Connectors of Cause & Effect
82.content:
Connectors link ideas. To master them, you must distinguish between those that introduce the Reason (Green) and those that introduce the Result (Cyan).

Group 1: The Cause (Reason)

[Result] + Because / Since / As + [Reason]

  • I stayed home because it was raining.
  • Since we have time, let's review the code.
  • As it is late, we should go.
  • The flight was cancelled due to the storm.
  • Because of the bug, users can't login.
  • He failed because he didn't study.

Group 2: The Effect (Result)

[Reason] + Therefore / So + [Result]

  • It was raining, so I stayed home.
  • The server crashed; therefore, the site is down.
  • He forgot his keys; consequently, he couldn't enter.
  • She worked hard, so she got the promotion.
  • Demand increased; thus, prices went up.
  • I was tired; hence, I went to bed early.
  • The API failed; as a result, no data was loaded.

83.title: Connectors for Adding Information
83.content:
These connectors are used to add more arguments, facts, or information to what has already been said. Each has a specific nuance and position.

1. Also

Usually connects ideas within a sentence or starts a simple addition.

  • She speaks French. Also, she knows Spanish.
  • It acts as a server and also as a client.
  • He is intelligent, and he is also very hardworking.

2. Furthermore

Formal. Adds a point that reinforces the previous argument.

  • The hotel is cheap. Furthermore, it is close to the beach.
  • The plan is risky. Furthermore, we lack the funds.
  • He refused to help. Furthermore, he insulted the team.

3. Moreover

Very formal. Adds a new, often more important, piece of information.

  • The data shows a positive trend. Moreover, user engagement is up.
  • Texting while driving is dangerous. Moreover, it is illegal.
  • The system is stable. Moreover, it is faster than before.

4. In addition (to)

Can be used as a connector or with a noun (In addition to...).

  • In addition to coding, he designs the UI.
  • We have a new server. In addition, we upgraded the network.
  • In addition to the salary, the benefits are great.

5. Besides

Informal/Spoken. Adds a strong, conclusive reason (often 'anyway').

  • I don't want to go. Besides, I have no money.
  • It's too late to start now. Besides, I'm tired.
  • Besides testing, do you have other tasks?

84.title: Uses of 'Even'
84.content:
The adverb Even is used to emphasize something that is surprising, unexpected, or extreme.

1. SURPRISING EXTREMES

  • He didn't even call me on my birthday.
  • Even a child can solve this puzzle.
  • She was so angry she didn't even look at him.
  • I don't even know her name.

2. COMPARATIVE EMPHASIS

  • This version is even faster than the last one.
  • It is even colder today than yesterday.
  • The second exam was even more difficult.
  • He became even wealthier after the deal.

3. EVEN THOUGH / EVEN IF

  • Even though it was raining, we went for a walk.
  • I will go even if you don't come with me.
  • He passed the test even though he didn't study.
  • We'll finish on time even if we have to work late.

85.title: 'Don't have to' vs. 'Mustn't'
85.content:
Don't have to = No obligation (You can do it if you want, but it's not required).
Mustn't = Prohibition (It is forbidden).

Examples (No Obligation):

  • You don't have to pay; it's free.
  • She doesn't have to come to the meeting.
  • We don't have to finish this today.
  • I didn't have to wear a uniform at my old school.

Examples (Prohibition):

  • You mustn't smoke in here.
  • We mustn't tell anyone the password.
  • He mustn't forget his medication.
  • Visitors mustn't touch the art.

86.title: Questions: 'What... like?' vs. 'How is...?'
86.content:
What is X like? asks for a description of personality or characteristics (permanent).
How is X? asks about health, mood, or current state (temporary).

Examples:

  • A: What is the new boss like? B: He is strict but fair. (Description)
  • A: How is the new boss? B: He is stressed today. (State)
  • A: What was the weather like? B: It was rainy and cold.
  • A: How is your mother? B: She is feeling much better, thanks.
  • A: What is your city like? B: It's noisy and crowded.
  • A: How was the party? B: It was fun! (Experience)

87.title: Compound Nouns: Open & Closed
87.content:
A Compound Noun is a single noun created from two or more words. This modal covers the two most common types: open (written separately) and closed (written as one word).

Pluralization Rule

For both open and closed compound nouns, the plural is almost always formed by adding -s to the very end of the complete word.

A) Open Compound Nouns (two words)

These are two separate words that function as a single unit.

  • The bus stop is just around the corner.
  • I can't find a parking space anywhere.
  • We're having dinner in the living room tonight.
  • You'll need your credit card to pay for that.
  • Is there a post office near here?

B) Closed Compound Nouns (one word)

These words have fused into a single word over time.

  • My keyboard stopped working, so I can't type.
  • Don't forget to pack your toothbrush before the trip.
  • I need to get some sunscreen before we go to the beach.
  • The kids are playing football outside.
  • Could you turn on the bedroom light, please?

88.title: Possessive Pronouns (mine, yours, etc.)
88.content:
Replaces 'My + Noun', 'Your + Noun', etc.

Examples:

  • This is my car. → This is mine.
  • Is that your bag? → Is that yours?
  • That is not her phone. → That isn't hers.
  • Our house is big. → Ours is big.
  • Their team won. → Theirs won.
  • His bike is red. His is red. (Same form)
  • A friend of mine.

89.title: Expressing States with 'to be'
89.content:
In English, we use Be + Adjective for feelings/states where Spanish uses 'Tener'.

Examples:

  • I am hungry. (Not: have hunger)
  • She is thirsty.
  • We are cold.
  • He is hot.
  • I am afraid.
  • They are sleepy.
  • You are right. (Tener razón)
  • He is wrong.
  • How old are you? (I am 20)
  • I am lucky.

90.title: Using 'Have Got' for Possession/Obligation
90.content:
Informal alternative to 'have'. Common in British English but widely used in US English for possession.

Structure:

I/You/We/They have got
He/She/It has got

Examples:

  • I've got a new phone. (I have)
  • She's got two brothers. (She has)
  • Have you got any money?
  • We've got to leave now. (Obligation = have to)
  • He hasn't got a clue.
  • You've got to be kidding me!
  • They've got a lot of problems.

91.title: Past Intentions: 'was/were going to'
91.content:
This structure is used to talk about plans, intentions, or predictions in the past that did not happen for some reason. It's the past tense of 'be going to'.

Structure:

Subject + was/were + going to + Base Verb

Examples:

  • I was going to do it, but I forgot.
  • She was going to call you, but her phone died.
  • They were going to launch the feature, but they found a critical bug.
  • He was going to tell you, but it wasn't necessary.
  • We were going to write it down, but we didn't know where.
  • It was going to be a sunny day, but then it started raining.

92.title: Idiomatic Expressions (Idioms)
92.content:
An idiom is a phrase where the meaning is not obvious from the individual words. You must learn them as fixed expressions. Here are 16 of the most common idioms used in professional and daily English.

Common Examples:

  • Bite the bullet (To accept something difficult)
    I hate dentists, but I have to bite the bullet and make an appointment.
  • Break the ice (To start a conversation)
    He told a joke to break the ice at the start of the meeting.
  • Call it a day (To stop working)
    We've been coding for 10 hours; let's call it a day.
  • Cut corners (To do something poorly to save time/money)
    Don't cut corners on security, or we will be hacked.
  • Get out of hand (To get out of control)
    The argument got out of hand and they started shouting.
  • Get something off your chest (To say something that was worrying you)
    You look stressed. You need to get that off your chest.
  • Give someone the cold shoulder (To ignore someone)
    I tried to say hello, but she gave me the cold shoulder.
  • Go back to the drawing board (To start over)
    The client rejected the design, so we have to go back to the drawing board.
  • Hit the nail on the head (To be exactly right)
    You hit the nail on the head with that analysis.
  • Let the cat out of the bag (To reveal a secret)
    It was a surprise party, but John let the cat out of the bag.
  • Miss the boat (To be too late for an opportunity)
    I wanted to buy tickets, but I missed the boat; they are sold out.
  • Once in a blue moon (Very rarely)
    I only see him once in a blue moon.
  • Piece of cake (Very easy)
    That exam was a piece of cake.
  • See eye to eye (To agree completely)
    We don't always see eye to eye on politics.
  • Steal someone's thunder (To take credit or attention away from someone)
    I announced my news first so he wouldn't steal my thunder.
  • Under the weather (Sick/Not feeling well)
    I'm feeling a bit under the weather today, so I'll stay home.

93.title: Causative Have: 'Have something done'
93.content:
The Causative 'Have' is used to show that the subject arranges for someone else to do something for them. The focus is on the object and the completed action.

Structure:

Subject + have (conjugated) + Object + Past Participle

Examples:

  • I'm going to have my hair cut tomorrow.
  • We are having our house painted next month.
  • She needs to have her eyes checked.
  • He has his windows cleaned once a month.
  • The company had a new app developed.
  • I had my wallet stolen on the subway.

94.title: Mathematical Operations & Symbols
94.content:
In English, mathematical symbols have a specific name (noun) and a way to be read (preposition/verb). It is crucial to know both the calculation terms and the action verbs.

1. Addition (+)

Symbol: Plus sign. Verb: Add.

  • 5 + 3 = 8 → "Five plus three equals eight."
  • Action: "We need to add the tax to the price."
  • Result: "The sum of two and two is four."

2. Subtraction (-)

Symbol: Minus sign. Verb: Subtract.

  • 10 - 4 = 6 → "Ten minus four is six."
  • Action: "Please subtract the discount from the total."
  • Action (Casual): "If you take away five, what is left?"

3. Multiplication (× or *)

Symbol: Asterisk / Multiplication sign. Verb: Multiply.

  • 5 × 8 = 40 → "Five times eight is forty."
  • Action: "You must multiply the width by the height."
  • Passive: "The value is multiplied by ten."

4. Division (÷ or /)

Symbol: Slash / Division sign. Verb: Divide.

  • 20 / 4 = 5 → "Twenty divided by four equals five."
  • Action: "We need to divide the team into groups."
  • Zero Error: "You cannot divide by zero."

5. Comparisons (> and <)

Essential for programming and logic.

  • > (Greater than)
    "10 is greater than 5." / "If X is greater than Y, execute the code."
  • < (Less than)
    "3 is less than 8." / "The budget is less than expected."
  • >= (Greater than or equal to)
    "Ensure the age is greater than or equal to 18."

6. Rounding (Functions)

Verb: Round.

  • Generic: "We should round the number to two decimal places."
  • Up: "Round up to the nearest integer." (4.2 → 5)
  • Down: "Round down the result." (4.8 → 4)
= (Equals)
"X equals Y" or "X is equal to Y".
% (Percent)
"50 percent". (Note: We do not say 'percentage' with a number).
( ) (Parentheses)
"Two plus three in parentheses".

95.title: Causative Get: 'Get something done'
95.content:
The Causative 'Get' is used to show that the subject arranges for someone else to do something for them, often by paying for a service. It's a common and slightly more informal alternative to the 'Causative Have'.

The focus is on the action being completed, not on who performs it.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Object + Past Participle

Examples:

  • I need to get my car fixed.
  • She got her phone repaired after she dropped it.
  • We are getting our house painted next week.
  • You should get your suit cleaned before the wedding.
  • Where can I get this document translated?
  • He got a pizza delivered for dinner.

96.title: According to vs. Based on vs. Depending on
96.content:
These phrases are often confused but serve three distinct purposes: citing a source, establishing a foundation, or setting a condition.

1. According to (The Source)

Used to say where information comes from (a document, a person, a report). It means 'as stated by'.

  • According to the documentation, this method is deprecated.
  • According to the weather forecast, it will rain.
  • According to Elon Musk, AI is dangerous.
  • Everything went according to plan.

2. Based on (The Foundation)

Used to say why a decision was made or what acts as the support/logic for something.

  • The salary is based on experience.
  • This movie is based on a true story.
  • We made the decision based on the latest data.
  • The algorithm works based on user behavior.

3. Depending on (The Variable)

Used to show that the result changes if the condition changes.

  • The price varies depending on the season.
  • We might launch today, depending on the test results.
  • Depending on traffic, I might be late.
  • Your access level changes depending on your role.

97.title: Adjective/Expression + Gerund
97.content:
While many adjectives are followed by infinitives (e.g., 'happy to see'), a specific group of expressions is always followed by a Gerund (-ing). Memorizing these as fixed phrases is essential.

1. Busy + -ing

Meaning: Occupied with an activity.

  • She is busy writing the report.
  • I was busy fixing the bug when you called.
  • The server is busy processing requests.
  • Are you busy working right now?
  • He is too busy preparing for the meeting.
  • They will be busy moving offices tomorrow.

2. Worth + -ing

Meaning: Deserving of time/effort; valuable.

  • This book is definitely worth reading.
  • It is not worth arguing about this.
  • The new feature is worth testing.
  • Is this movie worth watching?
  • It's expensive, but it's worth buying.
  • San Francisco is a city worth visiting.

3. It's no use / It's no good + -ing

Meaning: It is pointless; it won't help.

  • It's no use crying over spilled milk.
  • It's no good talking to him; he won't listen.
  • It's no use trying to fix this old code.
  • It's no good complaining without a solution.
  • There's no point in waiting any longer.
  • It's a waste of time worrying about it.

98.title: Mixed Conditionals
98.content:
Mixed Conditionals combine parts of different conditional types, usually the Second and Third. They are used when the time of the condition is different from the time of the result. This creates a link between the past and the present, or the present and the past.

Type 1: Past Condition → Present Result
