This type describes a hypothetical past action (that didn't happen) and its imaginary result in the present.

If + Past Perfect, ... would + Base Verb

  • If I had taken that job, I would be rich now.
  • You wouldn't be so tired if you had gone to bed earlier last night.
  • If we had bought the tickets, we would be at the concert right now.

Type 2: Present Condition → Past Result

This type describes a hypothetical present state (that isn't true) and its imaginary result in the past. This is less common.

If + Past Simple, ... would have + Past Participle

  • If I were a better programmer, I would have written that script myself.
  • If he wasn't so shy, he would have asked her out yesterday.
  • If I spoke French, I would have understood them at the meeting.

99.title: Compound Nouns: Hyphenated
99.content:
Hyphenated Compound Nouns use hyphens (-) to connect words, often to define roles, relationships, or to create a single, clear concept and avoid ambiguity.

The Plural Rule (Important!)

This is the key difference: the plural -s is added to the primary noun in the phrase, not to the end of the entire word. This is the most significant word in the compound.

Examples:

  • My mother-in-law is coming to visit for the weekend.
  • He is the editor-in-chief of a famous newspaper.
  • A passer-by found the lost wallet on the street.

Plural Examples in Action:

  • I have three sisters-in-law, and they are all very nice.
  • Several passers-by stopped to help after the accident.
  • The newspaper has had many editors-in-chief over the years.

100.title: Talking About Money
100.content:
Understanding how to talk about money in English involves knowing both the formal terms and the common, everyday slang. This guide focuses on the practical language used in the USA and Canada.

North America (USA & Canada)

The system and language are nearly identical in both countries.

  • Currency: The main unit is the Dollar, and the subunit is the Cent. The decimal separator is always a period (e.g., $10.50).
  • Key Slang: The most common informal word for 'dollar' is buck (singular) or bucks (plural).
  • Saying Prices: For a price like $4.99, the most natural way to say it is 'four ninety-nine'. The words 'dollars' and 'cents' are usually omitted.
  • Canada Specific: Informally, Canadians sometimes use 'Loonie' for the one-dollar coin and 'Toonie' for the two-dollar coin.

Bonus: Contrast with UK & Europe

  • United Kingdom: Currency is the Pound (£), with the slang term quid. The subunit is Pence (p). £10.50 is said 'ten pounds fifty' or 'ten fifty'.
  • Eurozone: Currency is the Euro (€). €10.50 is 'ten euros fifty'. Many European countries use a comma as a decimal separator in writing (10,50€).

Common Examples (US/Canada):

  • The total comes to twenty-five fifty.
  • Do you have anything for around ten bucks?
  • A coffee here costs about three seventy-five.
  • Can I borrow a couple of bucks for the vending machine?
  • You owe me twenty bucks from dinner last night.
  • This shirt is on sale—it's only twelve ninety-nine.
  • All I have is a fifty-dollar bill; do you have change?
  • The tickets were a hundred and fifty dollars each. (formal/emphatic)
  • Is it possible to pay in cash?
  • I'm trying to save some money for my vacation.

101.title: The Word 'Either'
101.content:
Either is a versatile word used to talk about choices between two options and to agree with negative statements. Its grammatical function—and therefore its meaning—changes depending on how it's used in a sentence.

The 3 Main Functions of 'Either':

1. As a Determiner or Pronoun (A choice of one from two)

Used to mean 'one or the other of two people or things'. It can be placed before a singular noun (determiner) or stand on its own (pronoun).

  • You can park on either side of the street.
  • I don't mind which one we watch; either movie is fine with me.
  • A: 'Which server should we use?' B: 'Either of the servers has enough capacity.'
  • A: 'Would you like the report in PDF or DOCX format?' B: 'Either is fine, thank you.'

2. As a Conjunction (Paired with 'or')

Used in the structure either ... or ... to present two exclusive options or possibilities.

either + [Option A] + or + [Option B]

  • We can either start the meeting now or wait for him.
  • The bug is either in the front-end or in the back-end logic.
  • For this to work, either the configuration needs to be updated or the code must be changed.
  • You must either accept the terms or reject them completely.

3. As an Adverb (Negative Agreement)

Used at the end of a negative sentence to show agreement. It is the negative equivalent of 'too' or 'also' and means 'también no' or 'tampoco'.

Negative Statement. ... negative auxiliary ... either.

  • A: 'I don't understand this issue.' B: 'I don't understand it either.'
  • If you don't go to the meeting, then I won't go either.
  • She couldn't find the solution, and her colleague couldn't either.
  • The first server isn't responding, and the backup server isn't working either.

102.title: Expressing Duration: Last, Take, For, During, Long
102.content:
To talk about time effectively, you must distinguish between the action of time passing (Verbs), the period itself (Prepositions), and the measurement of time (Adjectives/Adverbs). We have separated each concept into its own section below.

1. LAST (Verb)

Meaning: 'Durar'. It focuses on the lifespan of an event or object from start to finish.

  • The meeting lasted two hours.
  • How long does the movie last?
  • This battery lasts all day.
  • The storm lasted for three days.
  • Enjoy it while it lasts.
  • Nothing lasts forever.

2. TAKE (Verb)

Meaning: 'Tardar' or 'Tomar tiempo'. It focuses on the time required to complete a task.

  • It takes 20 minutes to get to work.
  • How long does it take to download?
  • It took me forever to fix this bug.
  • Don't worry, it won't take long.
  • It will take a few days to process.
  • This process is taking too much time.

3. FOR (Preposition)

Meaning: 'Por' (Duration). It answers 'How long?'. Used with a specific quantity of time.

  • I have lived here for ten years.
  • We waited for 30 minutes.
  • He has been working for a long time.
  • Can you hold this for a second?
  • I haven't seen her for ages.
  • We are going away for the weekend.

4. DURING (Preposition)

Meaning: 'Durante'. It answers 'When?'. Used with a noun/name of a period or event (not a number).

  • Please don't speak during the movie.
  • He fell asleep during the meeting.
  • I work a lot during the week.
  • It rained during the night.
  • We met during the conference.
  • Do not open the door during the flight.

5. LONG (Adjective/Adverb)

Describes length. Essential for questions ('How long'), specific measurements, and superlatives ('The longest').

  • How long have you been here?
  • The meeting was one hour long.
  • I have been waiting all day long.
  • It won't be long before we finish.
  • Superlative: The Longest
  • What takes the longest to load?
  • That was the longest day of my life.
  • Sending the video files takes the longest.
  • Whose commute is the longest?

103.title: Know vs. Get to Know vs. Meet
103.content:
These three verbs express different levels of familiarity. Confusing them is a very common mistake.

1. To Know (A State)

You use KNOW when the familiarity already exists. It is a state, not an action.

  • I know how to fix this bug.
  • Do you know David?
  • She knows this city very well.
  • We know about the delay.
  • I don't know the answer.
  • He knows a lot about Python.

2. To Get to Know (A Process)

You use GET TO KNOW to describe the process of becoming familiar with someone or something over time.

  • I am getting to know my new colleagues.
  • It takes time to get to know a new city.
  • We need a meeting to get to know the client's needs.
  • Once you get to know him, he's very funny.
  • She is getting to know the new system.
  • I want to get to know you better.

3. To Meet (An Action)

You use MEET for the first introduction (for people) or a scheduled gathering.

  • I met my wife in 2010. (First time)
  • Nice to meet you.
  • We met the CEO yesterday.
  • Let's meet at the coffee shop at 5 PM.
  • Have you met the new developer?
  • I meet with my team every morning.

104.title: Omitting Relative Pronouns (that, who, which)
104.content:
You can often omit the relative pronouns that, who, or which to sound more natural. The rule depends on what word follows the pronoun.

The simple trick: Look at the word immediately after the pronoun.

  • If the next word is a Noun or Pronoun (I, you, she, the team), the relative pronoun is optional.
  • If the next word is a Verb (is, lives, makes), the relative pronoun is mandatory.

Structure:

Case 1 (Optional):
...Noun + (that/who) + Subject + Verb ...

Case 2 (Mandatory):
...Noun + that/who + Verb ...

Examples (Case 1: Optional - Next word is a Subject)

  • The movie (that) we watched was amazing.
  • The woman (who) I met is the new manager.
  • I love the car (that) she bought.
  • The code (which) you wrote is very clean.

Examples (Case 2: Mandatory - Next word is a Verb)

  • The man who lives next door is a doctor.
  • I work for a company that makes software.
  • Can you pass me the phone that is on the table?
  • She's the developer who speaks three languages.

105.title: Quantifiers: A Few vs. A Little vs. A Bit
105.content:
The key difference between these quantifiers depends on whether the noun is countable (things you can count, like apples, minutes, friends) or uncountable (things you can't count, like water, time, money).

A few is used only for countables. A little and a bit are used only for uncountables. 'A bit' is generally more informal than 'a little'.

Structure:

1. For Countable Nouns (Plural):
A few + [Countable Noun]
A few of + [the/my/those... Noun]

2. For Uncountable Nouns (Singular):
A little + [Uncountable Noun]
A little of + [the/my/that... Noun]

3. For Uncountable Nouns (Informal):
A bit of + [Uncountable Noun]

Examples: 'A Few' (Countable)

  • I need a few minutes.
  • She has a few good ideas.
  • A few of my friends are coming.
  • Can I try a few of those grapes?

Examples: 'A Little' (Uncountable)

  • We need a little help with this.
  • There's a little traffic this morning.
  • He spent a little of the money you gave him.
  • I understood a little of it.

Examples: 'A Bit' (Informal Uncountable)

  • I have a bit of money left.
  • We're in a bit of trouble.
  • I'm a bit tired. (Modifying an adjective)
  • Could you wait a bit? (Modifying a verb)

106.title: 'IN' Expressions
106.content:
There are many fixed English expressions (idioms) that start with the preposition 'in'. These phrases often do not have a literal translation and must be memorized as a complete unit.

Structure (Lexical):

[Subject] + [Verb] + [IN-Expression]

Common Expressions & Examples:

  • in a good mood / in a bad mood (de buen/mal humor)
    The boss is in a good mood today.
  • in a hurry / in a rush (con prisa)
    Sorry, I can't talk, I'm in a hurry.
  • in love (with) (enamorado de)
    They are completely in love with each other.
  • in trouble (en problemas)
    He is in trouble for missing the deadline.
  • in charge (of) (a cargo de)
    She is in charge of the entire department.
  • in time (a tiempo)
    We arrived in time to catch the flight.
  • in the mood (for) (con ganas de)
    I'm not in the mood for a meeting right now.
  • in the way (estorbando / en medio)
    Could you move? You're in the way.
  • in touch (with) (en contacto con)
    Let's stay in touch after the project.
  • in debt (endeudado)
    The company is in debt after the expansion.
  • in shape (en forma física)
    I need to exercise more to stay in shape.
  • in danger (en peligro)
    The data is in danger of being corrupted.

107.title: The 'Get-Passive' Construction
107.content:
The 'Get-Passive' is an alternative to the standard 'be-passive' (e.g., 'it was broken'). It is very common in spoken, informal English.

While the 'be-passive' often describes a state, the 'get-passive' is used to emphasize the process, event, or change of state, especially one that is accidental, sudden, or negative.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Past Participle

Examples:

  • The manager got fired after the audit.
  • Employees get paid on the last Friday of the month.
  • They got married in a small ceremony.
  • A passenger got hurt during the turbulence.
  • The document gets saved automatically every five minutes.
  • The prototype got broken during testing.
  • My wallet got stolen yesterday.
  • The computer needs to get fixed.
  • The report must get finished by the deadline.
  • The loan application finally got approved.

108.title: Expressing 'Faltar' (To Miss, Lack, Be Left, etc)
108.content:
The Spanish verb 'faltar' has many meanings. In English, the correct word depends entirely on the context, such as absence, lack of something, or remaining time.

1. Absence (Not Attending)

This context differentiates between intention.

  • To miss (Involuntary): Used when you 'faltas' involuntarily (sickness, delay, obligation).
    She missed the meeting because she was sick.
    Hurry up or you'll miss the bus!
  • To skip (Intentional): Used when you 'faltas' intentionally (you decided not to go).
    I decided to skip the class today.
    Let's skip the introduction and get to the point.

2. Carency (Lack of Something)

  • To be missing (Lost/Not present): Used when an item should be present but is not.
    My keys are missing.
    A page is missing from this book.
  • To be short (on/of) (Not enough): Used when you don't have a sufficient amount.
    We're short on milk. Can you buy some?
    I'm $5 short to buy the ticket.
  • To be out of (Depleted): Used when the supply is completely gone.
    We're out of sugar.
    I can't print. The printer is out of paper.
  • To lack (Formal Carency): A more formal verb for a general carency.
    He lacks the confidence to speak in public.
    The report lacks clear data.

3. Time Remaining

  • ...left (Remaining): The most common structure for remaining time or quantity.
    There are ten minutes left.
    How much time do we have left?
  • ...to go (Countdown): Used informally to count down to a deadline or event.
    Five minutes to go!
    Two more weeks to go.

109.title: Common 'Work' Compounds
109.content:
These four 'Work' compounds are fundamental in business and technology, but they are often confused. Workaround, Workflow, Workload, and Workspace each refer to a very specific concept.

Workaround

A temporary or alternative solution used to bypass a problem or limitation.

  • The update has a bug, but we found a workaround.
  • We need a quick workaround until the system is fixed.
  • This workaround is not perfect, but it lets us finish the job.

Workflow

The sequence of steps or processes required to complete a specific task or job.

  • Our team needs a more efficient workflow.
  • The new software improved our workflow.
  • Please follow the steps in the approved workflow.

Workload

The total amount of work that a person or machine is expected to do in a specific period.

  • My workload is very heavy this month.
  • The manager tried to balance the team's workload.
  • I cannot accept more tasks due to my current workload.

Workspace

The physical area (like a desk or office) or the digital environment where work is done.

  • I need to organize my workspace.
  • The company provides a comfortable workspace.
  • This software offers a customizable digital workspace.

110.title: Pronouncing '0': Zero vs. Oh
110.content:
The pronunciation of the digit '0' depends on the context. Use 'zero' for formal or mathematical contexts, and 'oh' (like the letter 'O') for informal sequences like phone or room numbers.

When to Say 'Zero' (Formal / Math)

Use 'zero' (phonetically: /ˈzɪroʊ/) when you are talking about the number itself, in mathematics, science, or when precision is important.

  • The temperature is 0 degrees. (.../ˈzɪroʊ/...)
  • Any number multiplied by 0 is 0. (.../ˈzɪroʊ/.../ˈzɪroʊ/.)
  • The project has a 0% chance of failure. (.../ˈzɪroʊ/ percent...)
  • The countdown is: three, two, one, 0. (.../ˈzɪroʊ/.)
  • The final score was two to 0. (...two to /ˈzɪroʊ/.)

When to Say 'Oh' (Informal / Sequences)

Use 'oh' (phonetically: /oʊ/) when the '0' is just one digit in a longer, informal string of numbers. This is faster and more common in daily speech.

  • His number is (555) 890-0201. (...eight-nine-/oʊ/... /oʊ/-two-/oʊ/-one.)
  • Please go to Room 405. (...room four-/oʊ/-five.)
  • She was born in 1908. (...nineteen-/oʊ/-eight.)
  • I am using version 32.0.1. (...thirty-two point /oʊ/ point one.)
  • The meeting is at 08:00. (...at /oʊ/-eight-hundred.)

111.title: Preposition Stranding (Questions)
111.content:
In English, when a question involves a Verb + Preposition connection, the preposition usually moves to the very end of the sentence (it is 'stranded'). This applies to standard verbs and expressions of purpose.

Structure:

Question Word + [Aux/Verb] + [Subject] + Main Verb + Preposition?

1. Asking for Purpose ('What... for?')

When we use 'for' to ask about purpose or function (Para qué...), it implies the structure Be + For.

  • What is this tool for?
  • What are those buttons for?
  • What was that meeting for?
  • What is the extra parameter for?
  • What are you doing that for? (= Why?)
  • Who is this gift for?

2. Verbs with Fixed Prepositions

The verb stays with the subject, and the preposition moves to the end.

  • What are you listening to?
  • Who are you waiting for?
  • What is she looking at?
  • What does it depend on?
  • What are they talking about?
  • Who does this laptop belong to?
  • What are you afraid of? (Adjective case)
  • Who did you go with?

3. Phrasal Verbs (Separated)

  • Where do you come from?
  • What are you looking for?
  • Who takes care of the server?
  • What did you log in to?

112.title: Spanish Emphatic 'Sí' (vs. 'Yes')
112.content:
This explains why the Spanish emphatic 'sí' (e.g., 'mañana sí', 'yo sí') is not translated as 'yes' in English. 'Yes' is used to answer a question, not as an adverb for emphasis in the middle of a sentence.

Case 1: 'Sí' for Affirmative Contrast

This is used to contrast a negative statement (e.g., 'Hoy no, pero mañana sí.'). English does not use 'yes'; it re-uses the auxiliary verb (like 'will', 'do', 'can') to carry the emphasis.

Examples (Contrast):

  • Él no fue, pero yo sí.
    He didn't go, but I did.
  • No hoy, pero mañana sí.
    Not today, but I will tomorrow.
  • Ella no puede, pero tú sí.
    She can't, but you can.
  • A él no le gusta, pero a mí sí.
    He doesn't like it, but I do.
  • Tú no estabas, pero él sí.
    You weren't there, but he was.
  • Ellos no lo tienen, pero nosotros sí.
    They don't have it, but we do.
  • Yo no lo he visto, pero ella sí.
    I haven't seen it, but she has.
  • Este no funciona, pero ese sí.
    This one doesn't work, but that one does.
  • Tú no lo sabías, pero yo sí.
    You didn't know, but I did.
  • Él no debe ir, pero tú sí.
    He shouldn't go, but you should.
  • ...but tomorrow yes.

Case 2: 'Sí' for Confirmation/Emphasis

This is used to add strong confirmation (e.g., 'Mañana sí lo haré.'). English uses adverbs like 'definitely', 'certainly', or 'really'. It can also use the emphatic 'do/does'.

Examples (Emphasis):

  • Mañana sí lo haré.
    I will definitely do it tomorrow.
  • Él sí sabe la respuesta.
    He certainly knows the answer.
  • Sí que me gusta.
    I really like it.
  • Yo sí quiero ir.
    I do want to go.
  • Ella sí tiene el dinero.
    She does have the money.
  • ¡Sí que puedes!
    You absolutely can!
  • I will yes do it...

113.title: Punctuation & Common Symbols
113.content:
These are the English names for common punctuation marks and symbols used in general writing and technology.

Punctuation

  • . (Punto)
    Period (at the end of a sentence).
    Dot (for web/email addresses, e.g., 'google.com' is 'google dot com').
  • , (Coma) -> Comma
  • ? (Pregunta) -> Question mark
  • ! (Exclamación) -> Exclamation point (common in the US) or Exclamation mark.
  • : (Dos puntos) -> Colon
  • ; (Punto y coma) -> Semicolon
  • ' (Apóstrofo) -> Apostrophe (used in 'don't' or 'Pareto's class').

Quotes (Comillas)

  • " " (Dobles) -> Double quotes or Quotation marks.
  • ' ' (Simples) -> Single quotes

Hyphens & Dashes (Guiones)

  • - (Corto) -> Hyphen (joins words, e.g., 'well-being').
  • — (Largo) -> Dash (separates ideas in a sentence).

Brackets (Paréntesis/Corchetes)

  • ( ) -> Parentheses
  • [ ] -> Brackets (or Square brackets).
  • { } -> Braces (or Curly brackets).

Common Tech & Business Symbols

  • @ (Arroba)
    At sign. Read as 'at' in emails (e.g., 'user@mail.com' is 'user at mail dot com').
    Example: 'Make sure you use the at sign to tag him in the document.'
  • # (Numeral/Gato)
    Hashtag (on social media).
    Pound sign (on phones, e.g., 'press the pound sign').
    Number sign (formal, e.g., '#1').
  • _ (Guion bajo) -> Underscore
  • / (Slash) -> Slash or Forward slash.
  • \ (Barra invertida) -> Backslash
  • = (Igual) -> Equals sign
  • & (Y comercial) -> Ampersand
  • * (Asterisco) -> Asterisk

114.title: Beside vs. Besides
114.content:
These two words look almost identical, but that one little 's' completely changes the meaning. One describes location, and the other adds information.

1. Beside (Location)

Meaning: Next to; at the side of.

Memory Trick: Beside = By the side.

  • She sat beside me during the meeting.
  • The printer is beside the desk.
  • Put the icon beside the text.

2. Besides (Addition)

Meaning: In addition to; also; furthermore.

Memory Trick: Besides has an 's' like Plus (+).

  • Besides Java, I also know Python. (In addition to Java)
  • I'm too tired to go out. Besides, it's raining. (Furthermore)
  • Besides testing, do you have any other tasks?
  • Who is coming to the meeting besides us?

115.title: Been vs. Gone vs. Done
115.content:
This guide clears up the confusion between these three verbs when talking about events, life, and tasks. The key lies in The Mirror Rule (for questions) and The Agency Rule (who is doing the action).

1. The Mirror Rule (Contexto de Pregunta)

Listen to the verb in the question. In conversational English, we usually mirror it back.

  • Question: 'How was it?' → Answer: 'It has been...' (Focus on state/quality).
  • Question: 'How did it go?' → Answer: 'It has gone...' (Focus on progress/flow).

2. The Agency Rule (Contexto de Sujeto)

Done implies a person actively doing something. Events (things/it) cannot 'do'; they simply 'are' or 'go'.

Subject = Person (I/You/We) → Use Done.
Subject = Event (It/The party) → Use Been or Gone.

Examples: BEEN (State/Quality)

Use when describing how something was (adjectives).

  • The meeting has been productive.
  • It has been a long day.
  • The weather has been terrible lately.
  • Work has been stressful this week.
  • It could have been worse.
  • How has your week been?

Examples: GONE (Process/Movement)

Use when describing progression or outcome (often with adverbs).

  • Everything has gone wrong today.
  • The interview has gone really well.
  • It could have gone smoother.
  • My plans haven't gone as expected.
  • The day has gone by so fast.
  • How has the project gone so far?

Examples: DONE (Human Action)

Use when a person completes a task or performs.

  • I have done my best.
  • You have done a great job.
  • We could have done better.
  • He hasn't done anything wrong.
  • What have you done with your hair?
  • They have done it again!

Direct Comparison

Look at how the meaning shifts slightly:

  • It (the event) has been great. (Quality)
  • It (the event) has gone great. (Flow)
  • I (the person) have done great. (Performance)

116.title: Special Uses of 'Do' (Emphatic & Performance)
116.content:
The auxiliary verb Do/Does/Did has two powerful uses outside of forming questions or negatives: emphasis and describing performance/results.

1. Special Use: Emphasis (The "Emphatic Do")

Used in affirmative sentences to make the meaning stronger. It essentially means "really" or "truly". It is often used to contradict someone or show strong emotion.

Structure:

Subject + do/does/did + Base Verb

Examples (Emphasis):

  • I do love this new theme!
  • She does try her hardest on every task.
  • He insisted he didn't call, but he did call me yesterday.
  • Please do come in; we'd love to have you. (Polite invitation)
  • We do need that feature deployed by the end of the day.

2. Special Use: Performance (Do + Adverb)

Used with an adverb (like well or badly) to describe the results or quality of an action, job, or exam.

Examples (Performance):

  • I hope you do well on your presentation.
  • The company did badly in the last financial quarter.
  • How are things doing? — They are doing fine.
  • The team did terribly on the first sprint, but they improved.
  • She does exceptionally well in high-pressure situations.

117.title: The 'To' Rule vs. Direct Verbs
117.content:
In English syntax, transitive verbs are strictly divided into two categories based on how they handle the 'Recipient' (the person). Is there a logical pattern, or is it just brute force memorization? Fortunately, there is a clear pattern:

  • The 'Communication' Pattern: Verbs that involve explaining, declaring, or verbally sharing ideas almost always require 'to'.
  • The 'Transfer' Pattern: Verbs that involve giving, sending, or physically/abstractly transferring something usually connect directly.

Group 1: Prepositional Verbs (Communication & Ideas)

These verbs never allow the person to follow the verb immediately. You must use the structure: [Verb] + [The Thing] + to + [The Person].

Examples (Correct vs. Common Errors):

  • Explain the rule to me. (NOT: Explain me the rule)
  • Say hello to him. (NOT: Say him hello)
  • Suggest a solution to the team. (NOT: Suggest the team a solution)
  • Recommend this tool to us. (NOT: Recommend us this tool)
  • Mention the bug to the boss. (NOT: Mention the boss the bug)
  • Describe the issue to support. (NOT: Describe support the issue)
  • Introduce the new dev to her. (NOT: Introduce her the new dev)
  • Propose an idea to them. (NOT: Propose them an idea)
  • Report the incident to HR. (NOT: Report HR the incident)
  • Announce the release to the users. (NOT: Announce the users the release)

Group 2: Ditransitive Verbs (The 'Transfer' Group)

These verbs permit the person (beneficiary) to come immediately after the verb without 'to'. This is the preferred structure for fluency: [Verb] + [The Person] + [The Thing].

Examples (Natural Flow):

  • Tell me the truth.
  • Give him the password.
  • Send us the email.
  • Show her the screen.
  • Lend them your laptop.
  • Offer the client a discount.
  • Pay the vendor the invoice.
  • Teach the junior the framework.
  • Bring me the report.
  • Ask the lead a question.

118.title: The Perfect Infinitive: 'to have done'
118.content:
The Perfect Infinitive is a grammatical structure used to talk about the past when looking back from the present. It combines the infinitive 'to have' with the Past Participle.

Structure:

to have + Past Participle

1. With Reporting Verbs (Seem, Claim, Appear)

Used to describe an event that happened before the moment of speaking.

  • The server seems to have crashed last night.
  • He claims to have finished the report, but I don't see it.
  • The suspect appears to have left the country.
  • This bug is said to have been fixed in version 2.0.

2. With Modals (Deduction & Regret)

Used to speculate about the past or express regret.

  • He must have forgotten his password. (Strong deduction)
  • They might have missed the train. (Possibility)
  • I should have listened to you. (Regret)
  • We could have won the game. (Past possibility not realized)

3. With Adjectives

Used to judge a past action.

  • It was a mistake to have trusted that source.
  • I was lucky to have met her before she left.
  • You were right to have refused the offer.

119.title: Compound Adjectives (Hyphenated)
119.content:
When two or more words are combined to modify a noun before it, they are joined by a hyphen to show they act as a single idea. This prevents ambiguity.

The Position Rule:

  • Before the Noun: Hyphenate.
    A well-known author.
  • After the Noun: Do not hyphenate.
    The author is well known.

Common Categories:

  • Time/Duration: Long-term effects, Part-time job.
  • State/Condition: Up-to-date software, Old-fashioned ideas.
  • Quality/Description: State-of-the-art technology, Well-known actor.
  • Number-Noun: A five-minute break (Note: The noun is singular).

120.title: Strong Collocations (Adverb + Adjective)
120.content:
In English, certain adverbs naturally pair with specific adjectives to create emphasis. These are called Strong Collocations. Using the 'wrong' adverb (even if grammatical) sounds unnatural to native speakers.

Common Intensifiers:

1. Highly (Success / Probability / Standards)

Often pairs with positive, professional words.

  • The campaign was highly effective.
  • It is highly likely to rain.
  • She is a highly skilled engineer.

2. Deeply (Emotions / Beliefs)

Used for profound feelings or serious states.

  • We are deeply concerned about the issue.
  • He was deeply ashamed of his behavior.
  • I am deeply grateful for your help.

3. Perfectly (Absolutes)

Used to say something is completely 100% true/acceptable.

  • It is perfectly normal to be nervous.
  • She was perfectly honest with us.

4. Painfully (Negative States)

Emphasizes discomfort or unwanted qualities.

  • He was painfully shy as a child.
  • The process was painfully slow.

121.title: Time: Digital vs. Classic
121.content:
There are two main ways to tell time in English. The Digital method is easiest and very common in the US/Canada. The Classic method uses prepositions ('past' and 'to').

1. The Digital Method (Say what you see)

Simply say the hour number followed by the minutes. No prepositions.

  • 2:15 → It's two fifteen.
  • 4:30 → It's four thirty.
  • 7:45 → It's seven forty-five.

Special Rule for :01 - :09: Pronounce the zero as 'oh'.

  • 5:05 → Five oh five. (Not 'five zero five' or 'five five')

2. The Classic Method (Past & To)

Divide the clock in half. Minutes 1-30 use PAST (or AFTER). Minutes 31-59 use TO (looking at the next hour).

Minutes 1-30 (PAST)

[Minutes] + past + [Current Hour]

  • 2:10 → Ten past two.
  • 2:15 → A quarter past two.
  • 2:30 → Half past two.
  • 4:05 → Five past four.
  • 7:20 → Twenty past seven.
  • 9:25 → Twenty-five past nine.
  • 11:12 → Twelve minutes past eleven.

Minutes 31-59 (TO)

[Minutes Left] + to + [Next Hour]

  • 2:40 → Twenty to three.
  • 2:45 → A quarter to three.
  • 2:50 → Ten to three.
  • 3:35 → Twenty-five to four.
  • 5:55 → Five to six.
  • 8:35 → Twenty-five to nine.
  • 12:40 → Twenty to one.

3. Common Mistakes

  • O'clock: Only use for exact hours (9:00). Never say 'It is 7 hours'. Say: It's 7 o'clock.
  • 12:00: Say Noon (day) or Midnight (night). Avoid '12 o'clock' to prevent confusion.
  • Half: Always Half past two. Never 'two and half'.

122.title: URL Anatomy
122.content:
A URL is the address used to access resources. It is composed of distinct parts, each with a specific function.

https://bluemobile.sleemanfridge.ca/SleemanApp/api/searchKeyword

Breakdown:

  • Protocol: Defines the rules for communication (e.g., https or http).
  • Domain: The authority or address of the server (e.g., bluemobile.sleemanfridge.ca).
  • Path: The folder structure leading to the resource (e.g., SleemanApp/api/).
  • Endpoint: The specific resource or action being requested (e.g., searchKeyword).

123.title: Ordinal Numbers (Positions)
123.content:
Ordinal Numbers indicate position, order, or rank (First, Second), unlike Cardinal Numbers which indicate quantity (One, Two).

The Golden Rule: Most ordinals end in -th, but the first three are irregular exceptions that you must memorize.

1. The Irregulars (Top 3)

  • 1st → First
  • 2nd → Second
  • 3rd → Third

2. The Standard Pattern (-th)

  • 4th → Fourth
  • 5th → Fifth (Not 'Fiveth')
  • 6th → Sixth
  • 7th → Seventh
  • 8th → Eighth
  • 9th → Ninth (No 'e')
  • 10th → Tenth
  • 11th → Eleventh
  • 12th → Twelfth (f, not v)
  • 13th → Thirteenth

3. The Tens (y → ieth)

When a number ends in 'y' (20, 30), change the 'y' to -ieth.

  • 20th → Twentieth
  • 30th → Thirtieth
  • 40th → Fortieth
  • 50th → Fiftieth

4. Compounds (Big Numbers)

Only the last number takes the ordinal form.

  • 21st → Twenty-first
  • 22nd → Twenty-second
  • 33rd → Thirty-third
  • 154th → One hundred fifty-fourth

124.title: Catenative Verbs (Infinitive vs. Gerund)
124.content:
In English, Catenative Verbs are verbs that can be followed directly by another verb. The second verb must follow a specific form: Infinitive (to do) or Gerund (-ing).

1. Both Forms (No Meaning Change)

Verbs like start, begin, continue, like, love, hate are flexible.

  • It started to rain. / It started raining.
  • I like to sleep. / I like sleeping.
  • The cost of living continues to rise. (or rising).

2. Both Forms (Meaning Changes)

For verbs like stop, remember, or try, the grammar changes the meaning significantly.

Stop

  • Stop + Gerund (Quit): He stopped smoking.
    Meaning: He doesn't smoke anymore.
  • Stop + Infinitive (Pause): He stopped to smoke.
    Meaning: He paused his walk to have a cigarette.

Remember

  • Remember + Gerund (Memory): I remember locking the door.
    Meaning: I have a clear memory of doing it.
  • Remember + Infinitive (Task): Please remember to lock the door.
    Meaning: Don't forget to do it.

3. Strictly 'To + Infinitive'

Usually verbs of intent or future plans: want, need, decide, plan, promise, refuse, hope.

  • I want to buy a car.
  • She decided to stay home.
  • We plan to visit soon.
  • I hope to see you.

4. Strictly Gerund (-ing)

Usually verbs of enjoyment, ending, or suggestion: enjoy, finish, avoid, mind, suggest, keep, quit.

  • I enjoy reading books.
  • Did you finish working?
  • Please avoid touching the glass.
  • He keeps talking.

125.title: Common Uses of 'By'
125.content:
The preposition By is incredibly versatile. Its meaning changes completely depending on the context. These are the 6 most essential uses you need to master.

1. Proximity (Next to / Beside)

Meaning: Near or at the side of.

  • She sat by the window.
  • My house is by the lake.
  • Stand by me.

2. Method or Means (How?)

Meaning: Using a form of transport or communication.

  • I go to work by bus/train/car. (No 'the')
  • Send the file by email.
  • Contact me by phone.
  • We pay by credit card.

3. Method with Gerund (Action)

Meaning: Doing X to achieve Y.

  • You can fix this by restarting the server.
  • He learned English by watching movies.
  • Close the modal by clicking here.

4. Deadline (Time limit)

Meaning: Not later than.

  • Please finish by Friday.
  • I need the report by 5:00 PM.
  • By the time I arrived, he had left.

5. Passive Agent (Who?)

Meaning: The person or thing that does the action in Passive Voice.

  • The code was written by John.
  • The server is maintained by the DevOps team.
  • The decision was made by the CEO.

6. Reflexive (Alone)

Meaning: Alone or without help.

  • I live by myself.
  • He did the project by himself.

126.title: Pronouncing Years
126.content:
Reading years in English follows different rules than normal numbers. The pronunciation changes depending on the century.

1. Before 2000 (Split Method)

Split the year into two pairs of digits.

  • 1990 → Nineteen ninety
  • 1850 → Eighteen fifty
  • 1492 → Fourteen ninety-two
  • 1905 → Nineteen oh five (Use 'oh' for the zero)
  • 1701 → Seventeen oh one

2. The Year 2000

Read as a normal number.

  • 2000 → Two thousand

3. 2001 to 2009 (The 'Thousand' Method)

Usually read as 'Two thousand and...'.

  • 2001 → Two thousand (and) one
  • 2008 → Two thousand (and) eight
  • (Rare but accepted: Twenty oh one)

4. 2010 and Onwards (Both Methods)

You can split it (more common now) OR use 'thousand'.

  • 2012 → Twenty twelve OR Two thousand twelve
  • 2024 → Twenty twenty-four
  • 2030 → Twenty thirty

127.title: Win vs. Earn vs. Gain
127.content:
These three verbs are often confused because they all relate to getting something. However, the context is strictly defined by how you get it: by luck/competition, by work, or by increase.

1. WIN (Competitions & Luck)

Use WIN for contests, games, wars, or gambling. It implies a competition where someone else loses.

  • Our team won the championship.
  • He won the lottery last year.
  • Who is going to win the election?
  • She won a gold medal in the Olympics.
  • We need to win this contract against the competitor.
  • They won the war after five years.

2. EARN (Work & Merit)

Use EARN when you receive something in exchange for work, effort, or good behavior. It is deserved.

  • She earns a high salary.
  • You have to earn my trust.
  • He earned a promotion through hard work.
  • They earn their living as developers.
  • The company earned a reputation for quality.
  • I feel like I haven't earned this break yet.

3. GAIN (Increase & Process)

Use GAIN for an increase in quantity (weight, speed) or acquiring something abstract or useful (knowledge, access) over time.

  • I have gained a lot of experience here.
  • The car gained speed quickly.
  • He gained 5 kilos during the holidays.
  • Hackers tried to gain access to the server.
  • We need to gain control of the situation.
  • You will gain insight into the process.

128.title: Apart from, Except, Besides, and Other than
128.content:
These connectors are used to include or exclude information. The phrase Apart from is particularly versatile because it can function as both an addition (like 'Besides') and an exclusion (like 'Except').

1. Apart from / Besides (Addition)

Used when you want to add information to what you just mentioned. It means 'in addition to'.

  • Apart from the salary, the benefits are also great.
  • Besides English, she speaks Spanish and French.
  • Apart from being fast, the code is also clean.
  • Besides the main office, we have three branches.

2. Apart from / Except (Exclusion)

Used when you want to exclude one specific thing from a general statement.

  • I have finished everything apart from the last report.
  • The store is open every day except Sunday.
  • Apart from that one bug, the system is stable.
  • Everyone passed except John.

3. Other than (Specific Exclusion)

Similar to 'Except', it is used to identify the only thing that is an exception. It is common in professional contexts and negative sentences.

Structure:

Other than + [Noun / Gerund]

  • I don't have any hobbies other than coding.
  • Other than the UI color, the design is final.
  • There are no available servers other than the backup one.
  • She has no experience other than her internship.
  • Other than being slow, the script works fine.
  • Is there any other way other than restarting the system?

129.title: Verbs of Perception + 'Like'
129.content:
We use Verb + Like to compare a sensory experience to a noun. It explains how something seems based on our senses.

Structure:

Subject + Verb (smell, look, etc.) + like + Noun

Examples:

  • This room smells like old books.
  • You look like a movie star in that suit.
  • This chicken tastes like fish.
  • That sounds like a great plan.
  • This material feels like silk.
  • It looks like rain today. (Prediction based on sight)
  • She seems like a nice person.
  • What is the new boss like? He acts like a dictator.

130.title: Irregular Plural Nouns
130.content:
While most English nouns form the plural by adding -s or -es, many common words follow irregular patterns or change completely. These must be memorized.

Common Irregulars

  • Person → People
  • Child → Children
  • Man → Men
  • Woman → Women
  • Foot → Feet
  • Tooth → Teeth
  • Mouse → Mice

Ending in -F / -FE (→ -VES)

  • Leaf → Leaves
  • Life → Lives
  • Knife → Knives
  • Wife → Wives
  • Half → Halves
  • Thief → Thieves
  • Wolf → Wolves

Ending in -Y (→ -IES)

  • City → Cities
  • Baby → Babies
  • Party → Parties
  • Story → Stories

Latin/Greek Origins

  • Cactus → Cacti
  • Analysis → Analyses
  • Criterion → Criteria
  • Datum → Data
  • Focus → Foci
  • Phenomenon → Phenomena

131.title: Tricky Uncountable Nouns
131.content:
Some English nouns are Uncountable even though they are countable in many other languages. They never take an -s and always use a singular verb.

Advice

  • He gave me good advice.
  • advices / an advice
  • Use: a piece of advice

News

  • The news is good.
  • The news are...
  • Note: Ends in 's' but is Singular!

Information

  • We need more information.
  • informations
  • Use: a piece of information

Furniture

  • My furniture is old.
  • furnitures
  • Use: a piece of furniture

Work (vs. Job)

  • I have a lot of work.
  • works
  • 'Job' is countable (two jobs).

Bread / Toast

  • I ate some bread.
  • a bread / toasts
  • Use: a slice of bread/toast

132.title: 'Set' Expressions
132.content:
The verb Set is one of the most versatile words in English. It forms many fixed expressions (collocations) where you cannot substitute it with 'put' or 'make'.

6 Essential Expressions:

  • Set the table (Prepare for a meal)
    Can you help me set the table for dinner?
  • Set an alarm (Schedule a wake-up call)
    I set my alarm for 6:00 AM.
  • Set a goal (Establish an objective)
    We need to set realistic goals for this sprint.
  • Set an example (Be a role model)
    Managers should set a good example for their team.
  • Set a date (Decide on a time)
    Have they set a date for the wedding yet?
  • Set the record (Achieve the best result)
    He set a new world record in swimming.

133.title: University vs. College vs. School
133.content:
In the United States, these terms have specific meanings that can differ from British English or literal translations.

1. University

A large institution that offers both undergraduate (Bachelor's) and graduate degrees (Master's, PhD). It is composed of smaller 'colleges' or 'schools'.

  • Harvard University has a Law School and a Medical School.
  • She is doing research at the university.

2. College (USA Specific)

In the US, 'college' usually refers to a smaller institution that focuses on undergraduate degrees (4 years), OR a specific department within a University. Americans often use 'college' as the general term for higher education.

  • I am going to college after high school. (General)
  • The College of Engineering is part of the University.
  • Community College offers 2-year degrees.

3. School

In the US, 'school' is a very broad term used for any educational institution, from kindergarten to PhD programs. Students at Harvard often say 'I'm at school'.

  • Elementary school / High school.
  • Law School / Med School.
  • I have to go to school now. (Could mean University)

134.title: Log vs. Register vs. Record
134.content:
In Spanish, the word 'Registro' is used for almost everything. In English, we must be precise. The choice depends on whether we are talking about Data, Chronology, or Enrollment.

1. RECORD (Data & Permanence)

Focus: A permanent piece of information or a row in a database. It implies history and facts.

  • The database table contains 1 million records.
  • Her medical records are confidential.
  • We need to keep a record of all transactions.
  • He set a new world record in the 100m sprint.
  • The police have a record of his crimes.
  • (Verb) I want to record this meeting so I can listen later.

2. LOG (Chronology & Events)

Focus: A running list of events happening in real-time. Think of a 'diary' for machines or security.

  • Check the server logs to find the error.
  • Please sign the visitor log at the front desk.
  • The captain kept a log of the ship's journey.
  • We need to log a ticket for this bug. (Verb)
  • The system logs every user login attempt.
  • I can't log in to the application.

3. REGISTER (Enrollment & Official Lists)

Focus: An official list of names/members, or the act of signing up for something.

  • You need to register for the conference online.
  • The teacher called the register (attendance list).
  • The church keeps a register of all marriages.
  • Is your car registered in this state?
  • The cash register is empty. (Hardware)
  • Please register an account to continue.

135.title: Relative Clauses: Verb vs. Infinitive
135.content:
When you use that, who, or which, the form of the following verb depends on who performs the action.

1. Direct Action (No 'to')

Use this when that/who is the Subject doing the action directly.

  • They aren't errors that compromise production.
  • I need the report that details the expenses.
  • She is the engineer who designed this system.

2. With Infinitive (Has 'to')

Use this when the clause already has a main verb (like need, want), so the next verb is a complement.

  • These are errors that we need to fix.
  • The report that she promised to send.
  • The engineer who wants to design the system.

Comparison Examples

Direct Action:

"The document that explains the process."

(The document explains)

With Infinitive:

"The document that I need to read."

(I need... to read)

136.title: Proximity: Close to vs. Getting Closer vs. Coming Up
136.content:
English has specific nuances for describing how near something is. The choice depends on whether you are describing distance, motion, or a scheduled event.

1. Close to (Static State)

Best for being near a goal, a finishing state, or a specific time. It emphasizes the position.

  • We are close to finishing the report.
  • I am close to making a decision.
  • It is close to 5:00 PM.
  • We are close to reaching our sales target.

2. Getting Closer (Motion/Process)

Implies movement or time passing. Something is approaching you right now.

  • The deadline is getting closer.
  • My vacation is getting closer, and I can't wait.
  • The end of the year is getting closer.

3. Coming Up (Calendar Events)

The most natural way to talk about a future planned event (holidays, meetings, birthdays).

  • My birthday is coming up next week.
  • We have a big meeting coming up on Friday.
  • The holidays are coming up fast.

Quick Comparison

Event: The exam is coming up.

Time Passing: The exam is getting closer.

Proximity: We are close to the exam date.

137.title: Time Distance: "Away from doing"
137.content:
We use [Time] + away from + [Gerund] to express expectation. In casual speech, we often shorten this structure.

The Full Structure

[Subject] + be + [Time] + away from + [Verb-ing]

  • I am two days away from going.
  • We are a month away from starting.
  • It is one week away from finishing.

Formal vs. Natural (Short)

Native speakers often prefer the shorter version.

Long / Emphatic

"We're a month away from starting."

Short / Natural

"We start in a month."

Long / Emphatic

"It's one week away from finishing."

Short / Natural

"It'll be done in a week."

138.title: Expressing Coincidence (Happen to / By chance)
138.content:
How do you say "Por casualidad" in English? It depends on the structure of the sentence (Statement vs. Question).

1. Happen to + Verb

Used to say an action occurred without planning. Very polite.

  • I happened to see her yesterday.
  • Do you happen to know his name? (Polite question)
  • She happened to be there when I called.
  • We weren't planning to go, it just happened.

2. By Chance / By Any Chance

Literal translation. By chance for facts, By any chance for questions.

  • We met by chance in New York.
  • Do you have a pen, by any chance?
  • By any chance, do you have change for a 20?

3. Coincidentally

More formal or narrative.

  • Coincidentally, we were both there at the same time.
  • Coincidentally, they both applied for the same job.

4. It turns out... (Resulta que)

Used to introduce an unexpected fact/result.

  • It turns out that he's her cousin!
  • It turns out he's already been to Chile.

139.title: Job vs. Work
139.content:
A classic confusion. Job is a countable Noun (The role/position). Work is an Uncountable Noun or Verb (The activity/effort).

The Golden Rule

  • You can count Jobs: "I have two jobs."
  • You cannot count Work: "I have two works."

Correct Use Cases

  • She loves her job / She loves her work. (Both OK)
  • That's a tough job. (The role)
  • That's tough work. (The activity)
  • I enjoy my job / I enjoy my work.
  • She's doing a great job / doing great work.

Common Errors

  • Error: "He lost his work."
    → Correction: He lost his job.
  • Error: "I got the work!"
    → Correction: I got the job!
  • Error: "He starts job at 9."
    → Correction: He starts work at 9. (Fixed Phrase)
  • Error: "This job never ends."
    → Correction: This work never ends. (Work = The burden/tasks)

140.title: Gendered Professions (Archaic vs. Modern)
140.content:
English is moving away from gendered titles (ending in -ess). We now prefer Neutral Terms for almost all professions.

❌ Archaic (Avoid)

Do not use these feminized versions anymore:

  • Waitress
  • Actress
  • Stewardess
  • Hostess
  • Authoress / Poetess

✅ Modern (Use This)

Use these terms for everyone:

  • Server (Standard in US)
  • Actor (Male & Female)
  • Flight Attendant
  • Host
  • Author / Poet

Exceptions

Some historical or royal titles retain the distinction:

  • Prince / Princess
  • God / Goddess
  • Lion / Lioness

141.title: Collocations with "Enough"
141.content:
"Enough" pairs with specific adjectives to form very common expressions. Here are the top 7.

1. Fair enough

"You don't want to come? Fair enough." (Acceptable)

2. Good enough

"It's not perfect, but it's good enough."

3. Close enough

"We're not there yet, but we're close enough."

4. Hard enough

"You're not trying hard enough."

5. Strong enough

"Are you strong enough for this?"

6. Big enough

"Is this table big enough?"

7. Soon enough

"We'll find out soon enough."

142.title: Conversational Phrases: That + It
142.content:
Native speakers mix "That" and "It" to confirm, ask, or end topics.

That's it.

Confirmation

"Keep going... stop. That's it." (Eso es/Así se hace)

That's it for now.

Pause

"We are done today. That's it for now."

Is that it? / Is that all?

Question

"I only have two files. Is that it?" (¿Eso es todo?)

That's not it.

Correction

"No, that's not it. Try again." (Eso no es)

That's just it.

The Point

"I can't leave. That's just it." (Ese es el detalle)

143.title: The Uses of 'Rather'
143.content:
The word Rather is versatile. It can be an intensifier (like 'quite'), a corrector (like 'instead'), or a preference marker. The context determines the meaning.

1. As an Intensifier (Quite/Fairly)

It means 'more than a little'. Often implies an unexpected degree.

  • The exam was rather difficult.
  • It is rather cold today.
  • I was rather surprised by the news.
  • She speaks rather quickly.
  • That is a rather interesting question.
  • The server is rather slow right now.

2. As a Correction (Contrast)

Used to say "No X, but accurately Y". Similar to 'Instead'.

  • He is not lazy; rather, he is exhausted.
  • It wasn't a bug, but rather a feature.
  • The goal is not to win, but rather to participate.
  • We shouldn't blame him; rather, we should help him.
  • The problem is not the code. Rather, it is the database.
  • She didn't quit. Rather, she was promoted.

3. For Preference (Comparison)

Used in 'would rather' (Verb) or 'rather than' (Preposition).

  • I would rather stay home. (See Modal 41)
  • I chose Python rather than Java.
  • Rather than complaining, let's fix it.
  • We should deploy now rather than wait.
  • I drink tea rather than coffee.
  • He walked rather than drove.

144.title: Introducing Topics
144.content:
In English, there are many ways to introduce a new topic or refer back to a previous one (saying 'Con respecto a...'). Choosing the right one depends on the level of formality.

1. Formal (Professional/Written)

Use these in emails, reports, and meetings.

  • Regarding your request, we have approved it.
  • In regard to the budget, we need to cut costs.
  • With respect to security, we are fully compliant.
  • Concerning the delay, we apologize.
  • In reference to your email, here is the file.
  • As to the deadline, it remains unchanged.

2. Neutral / Spoken

Use these in daily conversation or quick messages.

  • About the party, are you coming?
  • As for John, he is staying home.
  • Speaking of bugs, did you see the new ticket?
  • On the topic of holidays, when are you leaving?
  • Regarding that, I have an idea. (Common in speech too)
  • In terms of speed, this computer is faster.

Common Mistakes

  • Regarding to the meeting... (Never use 'to' after Regarding)
  • In relation with... (Use: In relation to)
  • Respecting to... (Incorrect form)

145.title: Technical Actions
145.content:
In Spanish, the verb 'Hacer' is used for almost everything. In Technical English, we strictly distinguish between Executing an existing process and Creating a new one.

1. EXECUTION (Run / Perform / Execute)

Use these when the object already exists and you are putting it into action.
Never use 'Make' here.

  • I need to run the tests. (make the tests)
  • The system performed a backup automatically.
  • SQL cannot perform a SELECT on an Array.
  • We executed the script successfully.
  • Did you run the migration?
  • The job is running in the background.
  • I ran a few sanity checks.

2. CREATION (Create / Set up / Build)

Use these when you are bringing something new into existence.

  • I need to write/create a test case. (Not 'make a test')
  • We are setting up the environment.
  • He built the docker container.
  • Let's spin up a new server. (Slang for 'start/create')
  • She made a mistake in the code. (Collocation)
  • I created a new ticket in Jira.

3. The 'Do' vs 'Make' Rule

DO is for actions/tasks. MAKE is for creation/results.

    DO (Action)

  • Do a deploy.
  • Do the math.
  • Do your job.
  • Do a quick check.

    • MAKE (Result)

  • Make a decision.
  • Make a change.
  • Make a request.
  • Make progress.

146.title: Into vs. To
146.content:
In a technical context, when describing a change, conversion, or transition from one form, state, or destination to another, the choice between Into and To is critical. The best choice depends on whether a fundamental transformation occurs (Into) or if a simple destination/result is reached (To).

1. INTO (Transformation / Conversion)

Use INTO when the original thing becomes a new thing, crosses a boundary, or fundamentally changes its nature, type, or structure. (Implies a deep conversion).

Structure (INTO):

[Verb of Change] + [Object] + into + [New State/Type]

  • We parse the string into an Integer. (String becomes a Number)
  • The compiler converts the code into machine language.
  • The list is transformed into SQL rows.
  • The water turned into ice.
  • He changed the document into a PDF.
  • We cast the NULL values into a Number.

2. TO (Destination / Target)

Use TO when you are moving something towards a fixed destination, linking a value to a type, or stating the target of an action. (Implies movement or simple designation).

Structure (TO):

[Verb of Action] + [Object] + to + [Target/Destination]

  • The variable is cast to a String. (Target type)
  • I walked to the office. (Destination)
  • The value is rounded to two decimal places. (Target position)
  • The server is linked to the new database.
  • Please send the report to John. (Target person)
  • We need to convert the array to the new format.

147.title: Usages of 'Mean'
147.content:
The verb Mean is highly versatile. It functions primarily to signify meaning or intend an action, but the passive structure 'Be Meant To' is essential for describing function, purpose, or destiny.

1. To Signify (Definition)

Indicates what a word, symbol, or error code represents.

  • The red light means stop.
  • 'Hola' means hello.
  • I don't know what this error means.

2. To Intend (Active Voice)

Structure: [Subject] + mean to + [Verb].
Used when a person plans to do something.

  • I meant to call you yesterday.
  • She didn't mean to break it.

3. Be Meant To (Purpose/Destiny)

Structure: [Subject] + be + meant to + [Verb].
Used widely in technical contexts to describe the intended function of software or tools.

  • The update is meant to fix the bug.
  • This tool is meant to tighten screws.
  • We were meant to meet at noon.

4. Other Common Uses

  • To Entail (Result): "Lowering the price means selling more."
  • Seriousness: "I mean it!" (I am serious).
  • Importance: "Your help means a lot to me."
  • Conversational Filler: "I liked it. I mean, it was okay."
  • Adjective (Unkind): "Don't be so mean."

148.title: Embedded Questions (Statements)
148.content:
An Embedded Question is a question that is placed inside another statement or another question. In professional communication, they are used to sound more polite, less direct, or to express uncertainty.

The Golden Rule: No Inversion

Unlike direct questions, embedded questions follow standard statement word order (Subject before Verb). You must also remove the auxiliary verbs do, does, or did.

Structure:

[Intro Phrase] + Question Word + Subject + Verb

1. Questions with 'To Be'

The verb moves to the end of the clause.

  • I'm not sure what the problem is.
  • I don't know where the meeting room is.
  • It's unclear why the logs are empty.
  • Please tell me what the priority is.
  • I wonder who that developer is.

2. Removing 'Do / Does / Did'

The main verb must change to match the tense and subject.

  • I want to know how this function works. (Not: does work)
  • We need to figure out why the script failed. (Not: did fail)
  • I don't remember where I saved the file.
  • Can you explain what this parameter does?
  • I'm investigating how the error occurred.

3. Modal Verbs (Can, Should, Will)

The modal verb moves after the subject.

  • Please let me know how I can help.
  • We are discussing what the next step should be.
  • I'm not certain when the server will restart.
  • He's checking whether the script can run on Android.

4. Yes/No Questions (If / Whether)

Use 'if' or the more formal 'whether' when there is no question word.

  • I wonder if the database is connected.
  • I'm curious whether they approved the request.
  • Let me know if you need more information.
  • It's hard to say if the deployment succeeded.
  • Check whether the update is available yet.

149.title: Expressing Preferences: The "What I..." Structure
149.content:
When you want to emphasize specific likes, dislikes, or desires (translating the Spanish "Lo que más..." or "Lo que menos..."), English uses a specific grammar structure called a Pseudo-cleft sentence. It almost always begins with the word What.

1. "Lo que más..." (Maximum Preference)

Use this structure to highlight what you prioritize above all else.

What + Subject + Verb + the most + is + [Noun/Action]

  • What I like the most is simplicity.
  • What we need the most is more time.
  • What she wants the most is a promotion.
  • What I enjoy the most is coding in Python.
  • What they love the most is the new design.
  • What he misses the most is his family.

2. "Lo que menos..." (Minimum Preference)

Use this for things you like very little or wish to avoid. Note: If you strongly dislike something, native speakers often switch to "What I hate the most..." instead.

What + Subject + Verb + the least + is + [Noun/Action]

  • What I like the least is the commute.
  • What I enjoy the least is writing documentation.
  • What we want the least is a delay in production.
  • What she likes the least about the job is the hours.
  • What I hate the most is waiting. (Strong dislike alternative)
  • What users like the least is the slow loading time.

3. Grammar Tip: Gerund vs. Infinitive

Pay attention to the form of the action following "is".

  • Verbs of Feeling (Like, Enjoy, Love): Usually followed by Gerund (-ing).
    What I enjoy the most is sleeping.
  • Verbs of Intent (Want, Need, Desire): Usually followed by Infinitive (to...).
    What I want the most is to sleep.

150.title: Will: Modality, Willingness & Resolve
150.content:
The word will fundamentally represents volition (wanting or deciding). It functions as a modal verb, an adjective (willing), and a noun.

1. The Modal Verb (Decisions & Future)

Subject + will + Base Verb

  • I'll check that bug immediately.
  • We won't release the update on Friday.
  • Will you help me with the migration?
  • The system will restart in five minutes.
  • I will call you as soon as I finish.
  • They will probably find the error soon.

2. Adjective: Willing (Disposición)

Subject + be + willing to + Verb

  • What are you willing to do to fix this?
  • I am willing to work overtime this week.
  • She isn't willing to compromise on security.
  • We need willing volunteers for the testing phase.
  • He is more than willing to assist you.
  • How is his willingness to learn new technologies?

3. The Noun: Will (Voluntad / Testamento)

Noun: The will

  • Where there is a will, there is a way.
  • It was done against my will.
  • He showed strong will power during the crisis.
  • The lawyer read the deceased's last will and testament.

4. Short Answers & Ellipsis

[Subject] + will

  • A: 'Who will take responsibility?' B: 'I will.'
  • A: 'Will it work?' B: 'Yes, it will.' / 'No, it won't.'
  • I don't want to go, but I will if I have to.

151.title: Fractions: 'And a Half'
151.content:
When adding 'and a half' to a number, the structure follows a specific pattern depending on the unit. The most natural way in English is to place the noun after the 'half'.

Structure:

[Number] + and a half + Noun (Plural)

Examples:

  • I've been waiting for two and a half hours.
  • The project took three and a half months to complete.
  • We need one and a half liters of water.
  • It's been six and a half years since we moved.
  • The file is four and a half gigabytes.
  • He ran five and a half miles this morning.

Common Mistake:

- Two months and a half (Unnatural)
- Two and a half months (Correct)

152.title: Uses of "Meet"
152.content:
The verb Meet is highly versatile in both professional and social English. It primarily covers introductions, fulfilling standards, and adhering to schedules.

1. People & Introductions

Used for the first time you see someone or for scheduled gatherings.

  • Nice to meet you.
  • I met the CEO yesterday morning.
  • Where should we meet the client?
  • We are meeting at 5 PM.
  • I met my best friend in college.
  • Have you met the new developer?

2. Requirements & Standards (Cumplir)

Used when a condition or rule is satisfied.

  • The candidate must meet all the requirements.
  • Does the software meet the security standards?
  • We need to meet the criteria for the certification.
  • The product meets user expectations.
  • You failed to meet the basic rules of the office.
  • We strive to meet high quality standards.

3. Deadlines & Schedules

Used for completing tasks within a set timeframe.

  • We must meet the deadline by Friday.
  • It is hard to meet the current schedule.
  • We met the target for the first quarter.
  • Can we meet the release date?
  • They worked late to meet the production goals.
  • I am worried we won't meet the submission date.

153.title: UI Positions & Digital Navigation
153.content:
In digital interfaces, we treat the screen as a 2D map. Natural English uses specific prepositions: AT for vertical extremes, ON for horizontal sides, and IN for containers like corners or the center.

1. The Four Basic Edges

Use AT for Top/Bottom and ON for Left/Right.

  • The nav bar is at the top of the page.
  • The pagination is at the bottom.
  • The sidebar is on the left.
  • The scrollbar is on the right.
  • Watch for alerts at the very top.
  • The link is at the very bottom.

2. The Corners (Combinations)

Always use IN because we view the corner as a container.

  • Click the 'X' in the top-right.
  • The logo is in the top-left.
  • The help button is in the bottom-right.
  • The clock is in the bottom-right of the taskbar.
  • Notifications appear in the upper-right corner.
  • The version number is in the lower-left corner.

3. Center and Middle

Center: Exact middle. Middle: Between other elements.

  • The hero image is in the center of the screen.
  • The search bar is in the middle of the header.
  • Keep the modal in the dead center.
  • The icon is in the middle of the paragraph.

4. Scrolling & Sequence

For long pages or spreadsheets.

  • Go back to the beginning of the document.
  • The index is at the end of the file.
  • I am stuck in the middle of this spreadsheet.
  • Critical CTAs must be above the fold.
  • The footer stays below the fold.
  • Scroll to the top to refresh.

154.title: Spatial Navigation & Movement
154.content:
To describe movement or positioning in a UI or physical space, we use specific verbs and directional terms. This guide categorizes movement for clear communication.

Structure:

[Verb] + [Object] + Direction

1. Basic Directions

  • Move the window up.
  • Push the button down.
  • Shift the image to the left.
  • Drag the icon to the right.
  • Slide the slider upwards.
  • Scroll down to see more.

2. Combined Directions (Corners)

  • Move it to the top-left.
  • Position the logo top-right.
  • Drag the file to the bottom-left.
  • Place the notification bottom-right.
  • Move the header up and to the left.
  • Shift the element down and to the right.

3. Centering & Alignment

  • Place the text in the center.
  • Align the image to the middle.
  • Center the entire block.
  • Move the modal to the dead center.
  • Keep the content middle-aligned.
  • Bring the sidebar left for better balance.

155.title: 'Upward' Terms
155.content:
English uses specific terms to describe height and upward movement. Understanding the difference between static position and dynamic motion is key to spatial accuracy.

ABOVE (Static Height / No Contact)

Higher than another element, without touching it. Standard for referencing preceding lines in a document.

  • The header is above the main content.
  • Please refer to the diagram above.
  • The shelf is fixed above the desk.
  • A mirror hangs above the sink.

OVER (Coverage & Position)

Directly above, often covering or moving across from one side to another.

  • The plane flew over the city.
  • Spread the blanket over the sofa.
  • The bridge goes over the river.
  • He put his hand over the sensor.

ON (Surface Contact)

Used when an object is physically touching a surface or element.

  • The laptop is on the table.
  • Place the icon on the sidebar.
  • There is a scratch on the screen.
  • Keep your files on the desktop.

UP (Directional Motion)

Movement from a lower point to a higher point.

  • We walked up the stairs.
  • Scroll up to see the previous logs.
  • The elevator is going up.
  • Lift the lever up to unlock it.

OVERHEAD (Directly Above)

Located directly above one's head or the main area.

  • The lights overhead are flickering.
  • A drone is hovering overhead.
  • Store your bags in the overhead bin.
  • We heard footsteps overhead.

UPPER (Higher of Two)

An adjective describing the higher part of a structure or the higher of two things.

  • Check the upper menu for settings.
  • I live on the upper floor.
  • The upper case letters are required.
  • The upper limit is 100MB.

UPWARD (Pointing High)

Describes a direction or a trend pointing toward a higher position.

  • The smoke rose upward.
  • The trend is moving upward.
  • Move the cursor upward.
  • The path leads upward into the hills.

156.title: Uses of 'Kind'
156.content:
The word Kind is a chameleon. It can be a Noun (meaning 'type'), an Adjective (meaning 'nice'), or an Adverbial Softener (meaning 'more or less'). The context determines the grammar.

1. As a Noun (Type / Category)

Used to categorize things. Often followed by 'of'.

  • What kind of music do you like?
  • This is a different kind of problem.
  • We need a new kind of database.
  • These kinds of errors are common. (Plural)
  • It is one of a kind. (Unique)
  • I don't like that kind of behavior.

2. As an Adjective (Nice / Helpful)

Describes a person's character. Synonyms: nice, gentle, caring.

  • She is very kind.
  • It was kind of you to help me.
  • Please be kind to the new users.
  • He has a kind face.
  • Thank you for your kind words.
  • Would you be so kind as to open the door? (Formal)

3. As a Softener (Kind of / Sort of)

Used informally to mean 'somewhat', 'a little bit', or 'more or less'. It softens a statement.

  • I'm kind of tired today.
  • It's kind of cold in here.
  • Do you understand? Kind of. (Answer)
  • The color is kind of green.
  • He was kind of rude to me.
  • It looks kind of strange.

157.title: Under vs. Below vs. Down vs. Beneath
157.content:
To describe positions at a lower level or movement, English requires precision based on physical coverage, static rank, or direction. This guide separates these nuances into five specific categories.

1. BELOW (Levels & References)

Used for things at a lower level or rank, without physical contact or coverage. It is the standard for UI elements and document references.

  • Please see the table below.
  • The temperature is below freezing.
  • Click the link below the image.
  • His rank is below mine in the organization.

2. UNDER (Coverage & Authority)

Indicates being physically covered by something, vertically aligned beneath, or being managed/limited by a system or rule.

  • The keys are under the rug.
  • We are under a lot of pressure this sprint.
  • Check the settings under the Privacy tab.
  • Everything is under control now.

3. DOWN (Directional Movement)

Specifically used to describe movement from a higher point to a lower point. It focuses on the action or the change of state.

  • Scroll down to read more logs.
  • Please sit down and wait for the host.
  • The server went down due to a spike.
  • Put the phone down on the desk.

4. FURTHER DOWN (Position in Sequence)

Describes a location that is deeper within a long file, a list, or a timeline. It emphasizes the distance within a structure.

  • The logic is located further down in the script.
  • Find the variable further down in the class definition.
  • We will address that issue further down the road.
  • The update button is further down the page.

5. BENEATH (Formal & Abstract)

A formal or literary word for 'under'. It often refers to things hidden from sight or something that is below one's dignity.

  • The truth lies beneath the surface.
  • It is beneath him to lie about the error.
  • The folder was buried beneath many files.
  • He felt a tremor beneath his feet.

158.title: Prepositions with Superlative Groups
158.content:
When using a Superlative (the best, the fastest) to identify a specific item within a larger group, the choice of preposition depends on the nature of that group.

1. ON (Teams and Committees)

Use 'on' for structured groups where members are listed or belong to a roster.

  • He is the fastest runner on the team.
  • She is the most experienced developer on the project.
  • Who is the youngest person on the committee?
  • He was the best player on the field.

2. IN (Places and Physical Groups)

Use 'in' for locations, organizations, or general social circles.

  • It is the tallest building in the world.
  • She is the smartest student in the class.
  • This is the most expensive car in the city.
  • Who is the richest man in history?

3. OF (Comparing Individuals)

Use 'of' when comparing an item directly against a plural list or a total quantity.

  • He is the fastest of all the runners.
  • This is the best of the three options.
  • It was the coldest day of the year.
  • She is the kindest of my friends.

159.title: Idiomatic 'As ... as' Phrases
159.content:
English contains several fixed expressions using the As + [Adj/Adv] + As structure. These phrases function as conjunctions or adverbs and cannot be translated literally.

Common Expressions:

  • As far as I know (According to my information)
    As far as I know, the server is still down.
  • As long as (Provided that / On condition that)
    You can stay as long as you are quiet.
  • As soon as (Immediately when)
    Call me as soon as you arrive.
  • As well as (In addition to)
    She speaks German as well as English.
  • As much as (Even though / To the same degree)
    As much as I like the design, it is too expensive.
  • As many as (Up to a high number)
    There were as many as fifty bugs in the code.
  • As good as (Nearly / Virtually)
    The project is as good as finished.
  • As far as I'm concerned (In my opinion)
    As far as I'm concerned, this is the best solution.
  • As simple as that (No more to say)
    We just need to restart it; it's as simple as that.
  • As early as (At a surprisingly early time)
    The error appeared as early as Monday.
  • As often as (Whenever)
    Please update the logs as often as possible.
  • As much as possible (To the greatest extent)
    Try to optimize the code as much as possible.

160.title: Event as Subject
160.content:
In English, verbs of occurrence (Happen, Matter, Appeal) treat the Event or Thing as the subject. The person affected is the recipient, usually connected by the preposition 'to'.

Structure:

Subject (Event) + Verb + to + Recipient

1. Affirmative & Negative Statements

  • The error occurred to me while I was coding.
  • The idea appeals to him.
  • This rule doesn't apply to us.
  • That bug happened to her before.
  • Your opinion matters to them.
  • The task seemed easy to me.
  • This laptop belongs to the company.
  • The news appeared strange to us.
  • It didn't matter to me.

2. Questions

  • What happened to him?
  • Did the idea occur to her?
  • Does this matter to you?
  • Who does this belong to?
  • Will the offer appeal to me?
  • How does it feel to you?
  • Did the solution seem right to her?
  • Will the change matter to anyone?
  • How did the error appear to them?

161.title: State Verbs (Non-Continuous)
161.content:
State Verbs describe a condition or mental state rather than an action. They are almost never used in Continuous (-ing) tenses.

The Rule:

Use Simple Tenses only.

Examples (Correct vs Incorrect):

  • I know the answer (~I am knowing~)
  • She had a car (~She was having~)
  • What does this mean? (~What is this meaning?~)
  • I need a coffee (~I'm needing~)
  • Do you believe him? (~Are you believing?~)
  • We want more time (~We are wanting~)
  • I understand the logic (~I am understanding~)
  • This costs too much (~It is costing~)

162.title: Ellipsis: Avoiding Repetition
162.content:
Ellipsis is the omission of words that are understood from context. It makes communication faster and is extremely common in professional and informal English.

1. Verbal Ellipsis (Do / Does / Did)

Replaces an action verb previously mentioned.

  • He codes better than I do.
  • She worked harder than they did.
  • I don't like the UI, but they do.
  • Did you finish? Yes, I did.
  • The script runs faster than it used to do.
  • We need help, and they do too.

2. Modal Ellipsis

Repeats the modal (can, will, should) to avoid repeating the full phrase.

  • I can't go, but my brother can.
  • We won't join, but they will.
  • I shouldn't complain, but I should.
  • He can't come, but his wife can.
  • I wouldn't do it, but he would.
  • You must leave, and so must I.

3. Informal Question Ellipsis

Dropping the auxiliary verb (and sometimes the subject) in conversational questions.

  • You ready to order? (Are you...)
  • Seen the news yet? (Have you seen...)
  • Want some coffee? (Do you want...)
  • Going somewhere? (Are you going...)
  • Finished the report? (Have you finished...)
  • Feel better now? (Do you feel...)

163.title: Whitespace Characters
163.content:
Also known as Non-printing Characters. Computers treat these as data even if they are invisible.

1. Space (SPC)

Standard word separation. ASCII 32.

Symbol: [ ]

2. Tab (\t)

Used for indentation. Usually 4 or 8 spaces.

Symbol: →

3. Line Break (\n)

Starts a new line. LF (Unix) or CRLF (Windows).

Symbol: ¶

4. NBSP

Non-breaking space. Keeps words together.

Symbol: ·

164.title: Reduced Participle Clauses
164.content:
A fundamental structure for technical English. It allows you to be direct and efficient by shortening clauses.

The Golden Rule: Same Subject

The person doing the -ing action must be the same person doing the main action.

1. While + Gerund (During)

  • While debugging the script, I found a syntax error.
  • While updating Windows, I noticed a slowdown.
  • While monitoring the heart rate, the SmartBand recorded a spike.
  • While browsing the repo, I found old dependencies.
  • While testing the UI, I saw the buttons were misaligned.

2. Upon + Gerund (Result/After)

  • Upon completing the install, I restarted the PC.
  • Upon opening the app, I synced my data.
  • Upon reviewing logs, I found the cause of the crash.
  • Upon clicking export, I received a confirmation.
  • Upon inspecting the DB, I found duplicate entries.

Other Prepositions:

By: By optimizing the code, I reduced execution time.

After: After running tests, I pushed the changes.

Before: Before deploying, I verified the variables.

165.title: Future Perfect
165.content:
The Future Perfect is used to talk about an action that will be completed by a specific point in the future. It looks back from a future time to an earlier action.

Structure:

Subject + will have + Past Participle

Examples:

  • By 5 PM, I will have finished the code review.
  • We will have deployed the update before the weekend.
  • By next year, she will have lived in Chile for a decade.
  • Will you have completed the training by Monday?
  • They won't have arrived by the time the meeting starts.
  • By the end of the sprint, we will have closed all tickets.
  • I will have sent the email by then.
  • By tomorrow morning, the script will have processed all the data.
  • He will have graduated by next summer.
  • How many features will you have added by the release?
  • The server will have restarted by the time you log in.
  • I will have spent all my budget by December.
  • By the time you read this, I will have left.
  • We will have reached our target by Q4.
  • She will have fixed the bug before you arrive.
  • By sunset, they will have finished the installation.
  • You will have seen everything by the end of the tour.
  • I will have written ten chapters by next week.

166.title: Most vs. Mostly vs. The Most
166.content:
These terms are used for quantification and comparison. The choice depends on whether you are describing a majority, a frequency, or an extreme degree.

1. MOST / MOST OF (Majority)

Used as a quantifier to mean 'the majority of'. Use 'of' before determiners like 'my', 'the', or 'these'.

  • Most people like coffee.
  • Most of my colleagues work remotely.
  • I spend most of my time coding.
  • Most apps have a dark mode.

2. MOSTLY (Mainly)

An adverb meaning 'mainly', 'generally', or 'for the most part'. It describes a situation or frequency.
